Une odeur un peu citronné.  Une belle robe jaune brumeuse avec un mousse très généreuse et persistante.  Amertume modéré mais qui paraît plus forte quelle lest vraiment en labsence de sucré.  Un peu sèche.  Un peu terreuse (la levure).  Pas mauvais mais loin dêtre ma préféré de Dieu du Ciel.
chiara buona schium adiscreta persitenza naso speziato leggero erbaceo un tocco maltato delicoato in bocca buon corpo bilanciata armonica fresca

This beer poured with a huge head! It had a pale colour. Despite seeing all the other comments on aroma I couldnt smell anything that stood out. Quite disappointing there. The taste was a surprise. It started refreshing before quickly moving into a spicy/pepper middle section then finishing quite dry at the end. At the start I thought it was a bit too dry for me but as I continued I noticed that the dryness was less and less prevalent with each sip. Quite a nice beer. A bit too much going on for my every day beer but very nice!

Fanastic bright lemon and citrus.   Good alc, and nice carbonation that I think wrecks some belgian beers, this is the way... 

great palate, warm fruits, but the aroma is cracking!

<br clear="left">I poured an 11.5oz bottle into an oversize wine glass.Appearance: Dark gold/orange hue; hazy but opaque if the yeast is added. Forms a large, Duvel-like frothy head which laces and retains very well.Smell: Sweet, light fruits and some farmhouse funk, coupled with subtle spice notes.Taste: Belgian pale ales or blondes or singles rarely wow me. Dieu Du Ciel Dernière Volonté didnt either, but unlike most it didnt let me down. Its much stronger and fruitier than your average non-Belgian made take on the style. It begins fairly juicy and refreshing with orange peel and juice-like flavor and taste. Theres a slight hop spice through the middle, although its not a very bitter beer per se. It ends with a kick of black pepper and spice and a very drying sensation. Its interesting how a beer can be both refreshing and dry at different stages of the swig. While not as big and bold as Duvel, this beer definitely isnt as mild and ho-hum as most Belgian pales. Its in that strange void that few beers occupy with genuine flavor and reserved intensity. Nothing about the palate is amazing or unique, but its definitely more than just satisfying. Mouthfeel: Thick, soft but fizzy. Relatively clean aftertaste with minor spice dryness.Drinkability: This is a bottle-conditioned, Belgian-style beer (probably brewed with Belgian yeast), so its no surprise Dieu Du Ciel Dernière Volonté is quite bubbly. Carbonation does get stuck in the throat, although theres not a whole lot of spice dancing on the tongue - just a quick pepper bite. The 6.5% ABV seems dead-on as it has enough flavor and weight to do the job, but not something youd want to session or make a meal out of.
11.5 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $4.49 Very good!
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden with yeast sediments. Aroma and taste are fruits, yeadt, caramel, malt and hops. Great taste.
Pours hazy orange with an enormous head and strong lacing. malty aroma with Belgian yeast. Aroma of coriander and oranges. medium bodied and sweet. dry finish.

A - Pours a clear copper-orange color with a big finger-plus of frothy white head. The head fades super slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of strong yeast notes with some fruity esters and biscuit, alongside some sweet caramel malt, and some spices and floral notes.

T - Starts out with some sweet caramel malts and some yeast flavor with a mix of banana and biscuit. Through the middle, the yeast flavors get a bit stronger with some floral notes and spices coming through. The finish is a mix of yeast, sweet caramel malt, and hops that linger.

M - Medium-light bodied with lively carbonation. Feels smooth with a nice crisp and refreshing mouthfeel.

D - Very drinkable. Nice mix of Belgian and American elements. The caramel malts do a nice job of balancing out the strong yeast elements.

Bottle. Golden, hazy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate, malty - lightly wheaty and lightly sweetish aroma, some spiciness (coriander, pepper), some fruitiness and citrus. Body is medium, malty - lightly wheaty and lightly sweetish flavor, some spiciness and hoppyness, faint fruitiness and citrus. Finish is average, malty - lightly wheaty and dryish, sharp spiciness, faint fruitiness and  some citrus, some bitter hoppyness. OK dryish Belgian ale with peppery spiciness and light citrus.
Clear golden of color with a white head. An aroma of sweets, spice, yeast and dust. A flavor of spice, sweets, bitter, dust and a dry finish.
Draught at Holy Grale Zwanze 11. Light slightly floral body. Some spices. Orange body. Easy drinking.

341ml bottle from Broue Ha Ha. Pale cloudy gold with some nice sediment (thought I was careful) and a creamy white head that leaves lacing down the glass. Interesting aroma - combination of fruit, yeast, hops, bit of dry farmhouse, herbs with pepper and tarragon most prominent. Light and fresh but medium bodied, well carbonated, nice spices, mild sweetness with a hint of bitterness, good dry finish with some nice spice and yeast. Very good.

*Version 7%:Jaune/or et beaucoup de particules avec une tête crémeuse. Des grosses vapes de banane en arôme mélangé avec un gros bouquet de houblons épicés, assez intéressant. Au goût on a un bel éventail houblonné, du clou de girofle et une finale assez astringente. Bonne amertume florale bien installé entre les gorgés.
Draught from s. duyvil. Poured dark..  Fruit and malts collaborated. Very nice.

Bottle at home. March2011.

Light hazy beige-yellow colour, rich white head. Ester aromas of red apples, tangerines and herbs. Yeast is also present. The taste is slightly sweet, complex, still balanced. Malts, hops and belgoyeast present.  Some spices. Very nice take on a Belgian style!
Pours a cloudy, golden yellow with lots of sediment. Fruity aroma, and a fantastic spicy, malty, citrus taste that finishes bitter.

poured a golden honey color.  Full frothy head that remains.  Powerful aroma of belgium candy, yeast, some fruity citrus hop,  honey.  Med sweetness with some lite bitter.  Med body, creamy texture.  The beer starts off sweeter and fruity and ends sort of dry with a bitter finish.  Quite complex.  Would def try again.
Bottled 0.341L at Pikkulintu 6.2.2010. Mild slightly sour nose with some wine notes. Pale head. Pale golden colour. Some floating  particles. Strong fullfilled taste. At the end hoppiness.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2016 Couleur blonde-ambrée. Il y a tellement de particules en suspension que ça ressemble à une "Lava Lamp" des années soixante. Ça sent très bon; des odeurs de levure, de coriandre, de houblon et dagrumes nous titillent les narines. Son goût est assez acidulé, tel le zeste de citron et on y détecte de la levure, qui nous laisse un arrière-goût assez âcre et amer auquel on shabitue au fil des gorgées. 
Mise à jour: Plus intéressant que dans mon souvenir et cette fois-ci et plus belle.

Bottle; Pour is murky golden with an off white head that does retain fairly well; spotty, sticky lacing in this glass. Florals and fruits, bready malts and spices on the nose. Frankly; this is a nice, hop forward belgian - the floral hops mesh well with the dry hopping, spiciness, fruits, and spicy undertones. My only mistake was not realizing this was bottle conditioned during my pour.

one of the best "hoppy belgians" ive tried. bright aroma of grass, pine, citrus, and yeast. pours a fuzzy orange-y gold with small fizzy yellowish head. flavor is on the bitter side with some fruity sweetness in front and peppery spice in back. very dry, slightly astringent, bitter fruit finish.

Yeast and pale malt in the aroma while the appearance is gold-orange with sediment.  The flavor is mildly spicy and malty with some yeast.  A solid Belgian Ale which is taken down a bit by the earthiness of the malts, making a more straightforward Belgian Ale probably would have worked better.

Poured a hazy amber/orange color with a large white head.  Lots of sediment floating around.  Aroma is very sweet with light fruit and apples.  Very nice interesting yeast notes.  Taste is also light and fruity with some slightly tart yeast notes.  Very flavorful and well balanced.  Finish has some bitterness with pepper.  A bit floral as well with bread.
Bottle, Hazy dark gold-amber body with a alrge dense off-white head. Aroma:taste of biscuit, summerfruit and spices with a frim bitter finish. Medium to full bodied.

Pours a very hazy golden orange with tons of sediment floating about. Thick, creamy, white head that takes a while to dissipate. Aroma is very floral, citrus, belgian yeast, malt, honey, vanilla, hay, orange, lemon. Taste is very zesty citrus, orange peel, floral, malt, yeast; bitter hops come in slowly and take over near the end. Long finish of bitter orange peels, hops, yeast and malts. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy with very high carbonation. A very nice blonde ale.
A hoppy dubble. Aroma is citrus fruit and bananay esters. Nice malt on the tongue with a hoppy finish

In bottle; aroma is floral and hoppy with a bit of sweetness and spice. Taste is quite dry and hoppy with a strong tart finish. Overall, it is OK but they make much better beers than this in their line up. I wouldnt buy again myself

Cloudy orange, no visible carbonation. Frothy, lingering, beige-white head. Aroma is delightful and reminds me of orange, vanilla, citrus, herbs. Smells a bit like a wonderful creamsicle. Palate: medium bodied, slightly dry finish. Taste: very sweet, more bitter than expected, and very savoury. quite salty too. Quite a good beer.

Nice hazy chewy orange coloured body with a bright golden glow and a thin, one centimetre tall off-white head. Aroma of yeast, bubble gum, bananas, coriander seed, wheat and a nice candy sweetness. Medium-bodied; Strong spicey flavour at first with good malt and a nice yeastie touch with plenty of balancing sweetness and a good herbal hop note. Aftertaste shows a good bit of complexity with the yeast, alcohol and spices the clear winners on the tail end. Overall, a very nice beer and definitely worth trying! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Liquor Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 11-July-2010 sampled at home in Washington on 09-June-2011.

11.5oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours dark, opaque golden with a thick, lingering off-white head.  Aroma of floral hops, Belgian spicy yeast, and caramel malts.  Flavor a really good blend of these three.  Average texture.  A really good beer for this style.

Pours a dark, cloudy, pale brown with a big, frothy, white head and lots and lots of sediment.  The nose just reeks of massive amounts of bready belgian yeast.  Flavor is bread and lemon.  This is a nice and well-crafted beer, but I my socks remain on my feet.

A very strong flavored beer. Nice aroma of fruits, but the flavor is dominated by a dry hoppiness. The finish is almost astringent. A bit unbalanced in the dryness--a palate that counteract some of the flavors. Good, but not one of their best.

Appearance: hazy gold, with a thick white head slowly shrinking but never vanishing; lots of shimmering lace curtains--beautiful beer	.   Aroma: orange, lemon, flowers, some herbal hops, crackers.   Taste: like a less-sweet angel food cake, with notes of zesty citrus and a restrained flowery hoppyness.   Finish: 	champagne-like dryness, some light bitterness fading against crackery malts.   Notes: Delicious blonde ale.  Beautiful to look at, and well-balanced flavors.  Nicely done.

Bottle at home. Pours a pale golden with a big off white head. Sweet with a faint dryness. Aromas of caramel, grass and some floral notes. Also aromas of bread. Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Dry and bready finish.

341ml Bottle pours out a cloudy straw topped with a white head. Aroma was of belg yeast, caramel, a nice hop mix some floral, grass, pine, and a nice bread malt. Taste was much as the aroma with a good amount of sweet malts and some fruit.

Bière couleur de blé sur lie (malheureusement trop floconneuse) coiffée dun jolie col blanc.  Un houblonnage herbal aux arômes de résine avec une fin poivrée.  Amertume bien équilibrée au taux dalcool.  En bouche, un corps moyen, une texture lisse et une effervescence bien vivante.  Fin moyenne tout en arôme et en amertume.
Draft. Light golden pour with white head. Hoppy with fruit, spice and light herbal tones. Nice hoppy belgian brew.

cloudy, nice head,
lightly hopped, with grass, pine, some caramel sweetnes
full bodied, nice length and some light bitternes, delicious
a nicely drinking lightly hooped beer

Bottle from Taphouse Liquor store in West Vancouver. Pours a nice hazy blond with a fluffy, creamy white head. Aroma is lightly belgian yeast, peppery, light vanilla, earthy and herbal hops and some doughy creamy pils malts. Awesomely fresh pilsner malt flavour- doughy cream of wheat, lightly prickly spicy hops. Finish was delicate but succulent. Very solid.
Spicy with solid malt and some hop underneath. Very good beer, and different from typical belgian ales.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2011 Bottle served in a tulip. Hazy orange in color with a medium sized white head. Interesting nose of miso soup and fried shimp. This is my third rating of the night so my nose might be tired, but I swear this is what I smell. Light bitter flavor and a little salty from the soup... Ok, that might be my imagination. Light body, soapy fizz, and a dry, bitter finish. This isnt bad, but not up to DDCs normal high standard.

341 ml bottle.  Pours cloudy (yeast) deep golden in colour, with fairly big frothy white head.  Tonnes of suspended yeast and other bits.  Aroma and taste are nicely balanced, hops seem a little muted, but malt is sweet and warming.  Very drinkable!

Pours golden with a very fluffy, foamy white head.  Aromas of dry hops and sweet malt.  Balanced flavor with spicy hop and herb flavor.  Slightly fruity (apple and pear) and finishes with the complex hops.  Great beer that sets itself apart from the traditional Belgians.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 pours golden, slight hue and particules (yummy) with a 3-finger white head, excellent retention and lacing. aroma is of herbal and citrus hops, slightly floral - definitely dry-hopping. like tons of hop pellets. great yeast - some spiciness and fruitiness (apples, pears, apricot), even a little funky (some brettanomyces-akin esters). medium to full body - yes - oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation and great malty body. dry and relatively short finish, considering the amount of hops. hint of sweetness, some honey. ABV very well hidden. good to high drinkability. excellent brew.

Sensational, complex beer thats fruity, floral and spicy. Great looking hazy gold colour with a lasting head and lacing. Brilliant flavour and yeasty character.Carbonation is just right and has quite a dry finish. A def fav.
Nose is heavy yeast, barn yard, little lemon, weak late smoke notes, feel is broad, carb is heavy, taste is wheat??, dry lemon, then sweeter malt notes

Pours a hazy orange/copper (about 10 lovibond), heavily particulated with suspended flecks of yeast. The off-white head has great cling and resilience. The nose is bright and estery, with some impressions clove, gentle citrus, bubblegum yeastiness, and floral hops. The flavour is as the nose suggests and in delicate balance with perhaps a bit more heat than you might think. Honey sweetness exists in perfect harmony with floral hops, tangy citrus and bright phenolics. The palate is prickly, yet full-bodied for the style. Its benefits from appropriately aggressive hopping (most likely with noble styles), a long palate duration and a gentle reminder of the alcohol content with just  a little heat. Not quite sessionable, but I could slam about 4 of these before switching to something more innocuous. Kudos to Dieu Du Ciel!

Utterly flowery aroma. Bouquet of rose petals and citrus. Pungent green apple, slightly sour. Sweet and sour both. Touch of Belgian funk.

The appearance is honey-colored dark yellow. Some head, good with a vigorous pour. Tons of sediment. Excellent in a goblet.

Flowery flavor, with Belgian yeast. Very funky, with hints of perfume and sour apple and lemon. Sweet, lagery malts are a rather earthy base. Very sweet with an earthy, malty base. A puckery, funky finish.

Thick and gritty feel. Very dry, akin to a white wine. Leaves a tickle. A flowery, funky, earthy beer. Sweet, sour and fully of dryness. Really enjoyable.

bottle hooked up by phaleslu-  Thanks peter, lookin forward to this beer.   pours a hazy dark orange with a big, long lasting foamy crater offwhite head that leaves some tight lacework on the glass.   aroma of fresh grassy earth and peaches.  a touch of marmalade and pineapple.  hint of old spoiled fruit.    taste is toasted, burnt caramel and herbal wet grassy must.  unique, tasty beer.   liked.
Bottle. Pours golden with a nice white head. Aroma is rich saison yeast, vanilla, citrus. Flavor is very dry, slate, a bit hoppy and sweet. Very nice.

341mL thanks to tastybeer. The pour is a hazy, glowing yellowish gold with a massive, off-white, sheen, ice cream head. Big yeast floaties. Ice cream scoop retention. Big layered lace. Aroma is juicy citrus, vanilla, peach, saison yeast. Taste is saison hoppy bitter and dry, heavy on the stony/slate mouthfeel. Really good stuff.

Bottle. Moderate to heavy malt aromas of cereal and caramel, light flowers for the hops, light dough and earth for the yeast, with background notes of peach, white wine and faint spice. Head is fairly large, fizzy, white with some slippery lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is murky amber/tan. flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, watery with carbonation between lively and fizzy. It finishes moderately astringent and dry. This Belgian Ale has some really nice earthy aspects to it. The finish is a bit harsh on the tongue in spots , but the fruity/spicy start to it mostly makes up for it.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Sweetness, fruits, light herbs in the aroma. Flavour of herbs, sweetness, fruits some spice and flowers. medium to full bodied. Dry herbal bitterness in the en

A spicy, slightly alcoholic aroma. Nice head; good orange color. This a quite malty and grassy beer, yet it is still really good. Very creamy and smooth, but a nice spice bite. Excellent if youre craving something malty. Some orange as well.

On tap at Maxs. Poured into their royalesque chalice.

Light golden with pretty good head and lacing. Smells of soap and slight grain. Taste is about the same. Slightest hint of toffee and no real depth. Feel is light with prickly carbonation. Drinks light without much flavor.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-10-2010
Pours an opaque honey color. Aroma of banana, spearmint, bubblegum, spice.  Flavor is banana, bubblegum, spice.  Nice, but a little too soft in flavor. I was hoping for a bit more.
UPDATED: JUN 21, 2014 Pours hazy golden with a beige head. Aroma of caramel, orange, malt and fruity yeast. Taste of caramel malts, dried apricot, orange, bread, citrus and a hoppy dry end.

11.5 ounce bottle poured into Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Pours deep gold; more orange hued gold than yellow. Sediment is sparsely scattered throughout and is black and dust-like. 

Massive off-white head is rocky with long duration. Head eventually settles in uneven fashion. Plethora of Belgian lace. Dense, chunky, and thick head is like a huge slab of butter slowly melting on a warm pan. 

AROMA:

Belgian yeast, floral honey-like sweetness, light spice, subtle green apple, and a faint hop scent hidden behind the other aromas. 

Aroma also has a subtle sour-ish basement funk character, which was unexpected. 

TASTE:

Front of palate is floral honey malt with slightly vinous/sour character. 

Belgian yeast and pleasant amount of spice on mid palate. 

Back of palate is green apple. 

Finish has some hop bitterness. 

MOUTH FEEL: Medium body. Lively carbonation. Semi-dry. Faint tangy character is present on the finish. 

OVERALL: Quite pleasant. Seemed to really get a discernable amount of green apple in aroma and taste. Subtle vinous barnyard taste; with similar notes on the nose as well, though to a lesser degree. Almost saison-like; or perhaps like a combination of a higher ABV saison, a wit, and a small portion of lambic.

Light gold haze with a subtle spicy aroma. Theres bitterness along with a fruity tang that is really quite unique. Truth in advertising perhaps, as theres evidence of English and Belgian ales in this brew.

Lovely mouthfeel and a smooth finish. To describe it as a combination of ale types with some wheat beer touches doesnt really do it justice. A great beer from a truly remarkable brewery.
Bottle purchased from Rahman in Montreal.  7% version.  Gorgeous yellow, orange hazy pour with tons of sediment.  Crisp and smooth.. Great drinking with florals, wheat, coriander, yeast, citrus.

From a 341(?!)ml bottle on 31/1/2011. Pours a murky golden. Has a sharp yet understated aroma of fruit, spices and a touch of Belgian yeast. There is more spiciness and fruit (apples) when it hits the mouth, with a distinct bitterness which is dry and both salty and peppery (in a good way). A quite subtle but complex beer which is most enjoyable.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden straw color with a bubbly white head. Seems like its a little over carbonated, gives me a few inches of head then subsides back to a cap on top of my beer. My first whiff of this brew right after I opened the bottle was of citrusy hops. That disappeared after I got it in the glass, could be an anomaly. In the glass I smell a spicy peppery bready yeasty brew. Taste is yeasty peppery bready as well. The carbonation of the beer actually seems a bit light, weird! Medium body with a dry spicy finish. Good brew, I could drink a few of these.

Cloudy golden yellow with a rocky cream colored head. Aroma is apple cider, bubblegum, hay, and a hint of pine. Flavor is very dry, but only moderately bitter. Very well balanced. More hay and pine in the finish. Mouthfeel is astringent but very thirst quenching. A real treat.
bottle, pours hazy gold, massive head, floral aroma, honey, maltiness, flavor is peppery, floral and understated. nice beer.
Well done Belgian style beer but nothing extraordinary for my taste. The malty sweetness is counteracted by a citrusy bitterness and a heavy alcohol presence for a 7% beer.

Bottle at Black and Brown Inn, in Stockholm. It poured a very hazy yellow liquid with a slight hint of orange and a medium sized white head. Also some yeast floating in the bottle. Flavour of honey, yeast, fruits and also fairly sweet. Semi-smooth mouthfeel, medium thick body and high amount of carbonation. A very nice Blonde.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from Bruisin Ales. 
Aroma: The nose is spicy and fruity indeed with a powerful blast right out of the bottle.  I am sure the copious amount of carbonation helps things along.  A touch winey in the nose but with some Belgian yeast character and some sweetness.  Reminds me of a sweet German wine. 
Appearance: In pours a murky light brown with some gold and a large, frothy head of foam.  Lots of larger soapy bubbles.  Good head retention. 
Taste: The taste is much more mature and drier than the nose lets on.  Definite Belgian yeast characteristics but dry and fruity.  Nice apple and pear notes with a touch of spicy hops.  Very yeasty, but I didnt quite pick up all the florals they refer to. 
Palate: Light to medium in body with lots of carbonation leading to a dry and yeasty finish.  Smooth and enjoyable.
Overall: The ratings certainly do it justice as this brew is quite savory (except for the price tag).  Great subtlety and balance.  One of the best Belgians Ive had in quite some time.
Bottle LCBO. Pours cloudy amber with enduring thick white head. Heady aroma with fruit and spice notes. Sweet with bitter finish. This one is quite special, the nearest Ive tasted to Orval.

Complex flavors of hop flowers and spicy, fruity esters from the Belgian yeast are perfectly balanced with the robust flavors and aromas of malt. The finish is an assertive aroma from the dry-hopping. The soft golden color is a glorious jewel to look at. You cant get a more perfect head and lace. I wonder if the Canadians that live near this brewery know how world class it is? The Belgium aspect of it is mild. Tastes like a Belgium IPA. Delicious. Wonderful sediment in the bottle makes this beer world  class. Wow wow wow! $4.99  11.5oz.

Pours a dense amber body fraught with beautiful particulate beneath a creamy, lasting white head. Deep, fruity aroma... a sweet cocktail of cherries, peach, tangerine with a pleasing waft of alcohol as well as remnants of tea leaves, tree leaves and honey. The marriage of Belgium & England is well-played. Flavor leans towards the latter as the tongue is first met by the taste of an English IPA before it opens up to sweeter fruitiness, a cheesish yeastiness and, once again, a sweet drop of honey. Lightly astringent yet the flavors last with a complex sweet-yet-bitter spiciness. Quite incredible. ~~~~~~~ Single 12 oz. bottle from Archer Liquors, Chicago.

341ml bottle 
7.0% ABV (as marked on bottle) 
I tried this beer on October 1, 2010 at "Smokeless Joes" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a hazy gold colour with a huge frotyhy white head that persisted.  The aroma was yeast, some hops, and sweet malt.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was yeast, citrus, some sweet malt, and spices.

The beer has nice citrus aroma with yeasty underontes. It pours a nice hazy orange with a lingering light foam. It has a nice balance of bitter and sweet that lingers on the tounge. An excellent selection!

from Mondial de la Bière, Strasbourg - dark cloudy orange colour with a persistent pale beige foam; nice lace; perfumy aroma of grapefruit, candi sugar and esters; juicy palate and medium to full malt backbone; hints of banana; some sweetness and a solid astringent bitterness; long bitter hoppy finish with notes of honey, grapefruit and caramel - absolutely superb

Nice amber color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, floral, fruit, & spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, fruit, spicy hops, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, well done - I enjoyed  it.
Draft and bottle.  Pours a golden body with a white head.  Mild fruit tones, hints of apples, pears, and apricots.  Nice herbal body with a hint of cinnamon spice.  Really loving this one!

Bottle, 6.5%. Spicy aroma, some green apple, cinnamon. Cloudy grey orange colour. Good stable white head. The flavour starts off a little sweet, fruity and spicy. Turns more alcoholic with melony fruit notes. Even seems to have a hint of chilli in the finish. High carbonation.
Hazy golden colour with foamy white head. Spicy aroma, with fruit touches. Very bitter flavouring, almost harsh. I found it just too bitter.
Bottle. Pours hazy orangish with a beige head. Nice belgian yeasty, spicy, and flowery aroma. The flavor has light fruity notes, belgian yeast, and flowery notes. Solid.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2011 341ml Bottle. Pours a golden amber color with a thin head. Aroma consists slightly of spice w/ notes of banana. Flavors of hops up front w/ a slight sweetness. Mild at first then turns into a slight bitterness. Overall a great  beer by a fantastic brewery.

11.5-oz bottle Philippes Lafayette, LA - Aroma: citrus, piney, crystal malt, raisin; Appearance: cloudy, golden-yellow color, off-white color head, some laces; Flavor: sweet, salty, bitter, grapefruit, piney, ; Mouthfeel: medium bodied, average carbonation; Overall: an amazing aroma of hops and malt but the disappointing flavor of crystal sweetness, and beer.  Missing the sugar and malt complexity.  However, the dry hopping adds a great complexity to the beer..
Draft: pours golden amber with a white head, sweet aroma and taste, some citrus as well.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2010 Tasted from a 12 oz bottle purchased in Denver, Colorado.  Hazy orange appearance with a thick white head.  Sweet candy head thats highly yeasty with alcohol.  Sweet bread-like texture and flavor.  Thick, yeasty, fruity.  Really tastes like liquid bread for better or worse.  Bitter finish.

Big offwhite head. Hazy deep yellow body with strong carbonation. Milky fruity papery aroma with resiny spicy notes. Dry-sweet spicy milky honeyish taste with resiny fruity notes. Slightly hot mouthfeel. Mid-bodied. Dry resiny earthy citric aftertaste with tropical fruit notes. Nice, but a bit milky and harsh. Possibly a bit old. (0.341l bottle, Ølbutikken, Copenhagen.)

Bottle. Cloudy yellow beverage with a touch of orange. Lively aromas of cinnamon and allspice. The high alcohol content is quite noticeable, which adds an astringent bitterness. Spicy flavour even has a touch of heat, plus banana and lemon rind. Tight carbonation. Alcohol a little too omnipresent in this brew.
Cider-orange with big foamy head. Aroma is caramel, citrus hops. Flavor is bitter hops and fruit. Good but not too exciting.

This is an amazing blonde ale.  Wow, the fruit and spice are just outstanding, I could easily down another 2 or 3 of these.  The aroma is dominated by banana and some citrus with spice.   The flavor is much more neutral with just a little sweetness up front and a mild but very delicious bitterness in the back.  I would have liked a little stronger flavor, but that would probably be out of character for this beer.  Overall, I loved this beer, it exceeded my every expectation.  Best of all was the palate which was perfectly rich and smooth.
Bottle from Ølbutikken. Cloudy golden with a big, rocky head.  Lemony, yeasty, bready aroma. Great complexity, bready, lemony, a bit vinous. Semi-dry finish. Very accomplished.

341 ml bottle.  Amber and hazy. Medium-sized white fine-laced white head. Bold appley aroma and Belgian yeast esters. Crisp carbonation mixed with tannic bready flavours. Lots of tannins and hops bitterness. Rather odd beer, with classic Belgian characteristics, but with hints of cider and mouth puckering cider apples. Finish is dry and bitter.
Bottle. Pours cloudy golden. Nose of hops, yeast and fruit. Taste is citrus, extremely bready malts and yeast. Very bready.
From a bottle poured a hazy straw color with a good amount of head.  Light spicy malty flavor with a quick finish.

341ml bottle from the LCBO.  Pours a cloudy amber, with lots of yeast floating in it.  A thick white head didnt dissapate at all for the 10 minutes I let it sit to warm after pouring.  Aroma is dusty Belgian yeast.  Nice rich mouthfeel, and a dry, slightly bitter finish.  Reminds me of Orval actually.  Nice beer!

12 oz bottle poured a golden color with a pillowy white head.  Aroma has notes of doughy belgian yeast, pepper spices, bitter hops, and sweet malts.  There is a lot going on in this beer for a golden ale.  Palate is medium body with significant carbonation.  Taste is of Belgian yeastiness and floral hops with a nice balance of peppery spice and bitter hops and malt sweetness.   Overall, very good, but not my favorite from this great brewery.

Hazy, pale yellow, white head, good lace. Sweetish, fruity, well hopped but not extreme, hints of citrus and grass.
Keg.  Medium hop bitterness but big floral hop flavour and aroma.  Fruity and yeast flavours.  Mostly dry finish.

bottle poured a golden in color with a fluffy white head that retained a covering. aroma has belgian yeast, peppery spice, flowery hops, and sweet malts. mouth feel is light and there is plenty of carbonation. flavor has a decent malted base, belgian spices, estery yeast, bitter flowery hops, and a light bit of sweetness.

Ah, Dieu du Ciel! You never fail me. It pours hazy golden orange with a froathy, creamy white head with good lacing and retention. The aroma is spicey, fruity, citrus, lemon, orange, candy. The flavour is a pretty good reflection of the aroma, a touch of hop bitterness in the dry finish. Its good. Not really my thing. But its good.

330mL bottle, pours hazy golden with a big white head. Wonderful aroma of hop flowers, spices, fruity esters, yeast, citrus and orange zest. Flavour follows accordingly, with spices and orange zest up front, and hops and citrus on the finish. Excellent Belgian ale.

Blond hazy body, some floaters, white head. Has lots on aroma, yeast, citrus hops, alcohol, some herbal sweetness and maltiness. Flavour is a little bit too harsh, nice yeast coming through. Too bitter for a blonde. Quite typical for an american belge. Too hop oriented.

Pours a slightly hazy amber with a sumptuously big, foamy, lingering head.  Its an odd beer, but thats par for the course with ddc.  Odd because its got belgian fruity yeastiness, crisp spiciness from the wheat, dry hopping, and punchy alcohol!  Whew!  So its exceptionally complex and an intellectual challenge as much as everything - sorting out what youre tasting is very difficult.  So whats there?  Raisin, grapefruit, lemon, floral hops, pepper, alcohol.  And some biscuity malts underneath it all.  Finish is a bit too alcoholic for my taste, but lasts forever.
Strong blonde ale. The sort that throws you off on the first sip, but that you cant help but love as the evening goes on. Sweet and alcoholic all the same. Good one.

I like DdC and will always give one of their releases a try, even if I think they are a little overpriced.  Spooky, quasi-religious drawing on the label of a ...dead man?  A dying saint?  Very fine floral hop aroma (from dry hopping, according to the label).  Cloudy, tan pour with a cushy head, like a good abbey ale should have.  It also tastes like a good Belgian blonde should.  Nicely bittered, but not heavy.  It has some nutty notes, mild sweetness, and is naturally well-carbonated.  A very nice blonde and one of this brewerys best releases.

341ml Bottle. 7%ABV. Pours cloudy light orange yellow with nice tight white head lacing the glass. Fresh grassy hop aromas with a pleasant yeast character and light malt aroma. Characteristic Belgian yeast profile, medium-light body with flavours of orange zest and a wonderful lingering grapefruit/bitterness right through the finish.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2013 341ml bottle.  Im re-rating this because it just seems to have improved so damn much since I last had it.  Pours a hazy pale orange with a three finger head of fine off-white bubbles.  Smells amazing.  Yeasty notes, with lemon, black peppercorn, and beautiful floral / fruity hops.  As for taste, theres some definite booze up front, with tropical fruit, spice, light honey, and some earthy, metallic bitterness in the finish.  Imagine taking a Duvel, then adding centennial hops to it.  This is damn good, and far more complex than I remember it.  Well done.

Bottle:

Decants a hazed golden ale in the glass with a massive cap that lasts out the drink.

Aromas of apricot, spice, honey, some musty earthiness...Im shocked at how close this aroma is to Schneider Hopfenweiss...gorgeous!

Sandy mouth feel, light body, fruity-hoppy character.

Lovely rush of sweet malt in thefront is instantly balanced with leafy-hearbal bittering and fruity esters...subtle complexity mid palate - eartgy-mustiness mingles with honeyed grassy tones leading to a crisp dry finish.

Excellent rendition of Orval, less complex but more drinkable.

Comes in bottles now at the LCBO, with 7% ABV. Pours a cloudy beige-orange colour with a big amount of tiny particles floating everywhere. Its off-white head is beautifully creamy, long lasting and creates great lacing. Nice aromas of spices, Belgian yeast, mild earth and quite hoppy as well. Refreshing dry mouthfeel. The taste has the hop, again well-balanced, with a good mix of sweet fruits and the Belgian goodies. Very well-balanced Belgian-style beer that I would drink anytime.

11.5 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy bright orange with a medium white head of good duration and lacing. Nose is earthy yeasts with orange and fresh coriander elements and subtle candy sugar. Tastes quite bitter at first but becomes sweeter with each sip. Decent lingering dry hop bitterness to the finish. Medium-full bodied with an easy drinkability. Classy stuff but expensive Down Under.

Pours a hazy golden color with a slight orange hue and a white soapy head.  Has a funky, yeasty aroma.  Hints of citrus, perhaps tangerine.  Sweet tangerine like flavor with a nicy maltiness that provides a creamy mouthfeel with a nice layer of bitters on the back end through the finish.
Bière forte de 7 % dalcool. Jaurais tendance à croire que cétait une bière blanche, mais jen suis toujours indécis. Un bon goût fruité et floral, un léger goût de malt. Très bonne bière.
Orange brown pour. A little funky. Belgian spice in the nose. Some hops in the aroma. A little sweet, a little bitter, a little spicy. Ok.

Draught Moose & Mountie Spectapular, Sydney.
Golden beer with tight white head. Lots of floral aromatics and ripe fruits like peach and apricot, maybe even a bit of grass in there. Bit more bitter than your average Belgian blond with a hint of warmth on the finish.

Bottle. Moderately malted with light grain and citrus in the nose. Poured lightly fizzy with moderate head retention. A robust amber-orange color which was moderately bitter in the initial flavor as well as the finish. This was a good drink.. both bottles. One was 6.5 ABV and the other was 7.0 ABV. Not sure why the difference, but there seemed to be a label change as well. Regardless we enjoyed the 6.5 over the 7 hands down.

We tried two bottles, one a 6.5%, one a 7%.  Pours a hazy yellow.

The 7% bottle was much more bitter, large particles of sediment floating in it.  An acidic initial flavor with a bitter alcoholic finish.  Not very pleasant. 

The 6.5% bottle was much milder. and have a better flavor, cleaner taste.  Less sediment and was fairly clear.

11.5 fl. oz. bottle (no idea what that is in ml). Pours a hazy light amber, with a pillowy head and good lacing. That head does somewhat mute the aroma, but there are hints of pine and grapefruit there. It smells a little too acidic, however, which does not bode well for its balance. There are powerful citrus hops to begin, moving into a mild hint of pineapple and a fairly bland malt finish. This is an odd beer. It seems, in flavour at least, to sit somewhere between a wit, an abbey ale and a blond ale, but it doesnt really get the best of any of these styles. A sadly flawed beer.

From bottle...amber orange, cloudy, full foamy head quickly dissipates.  Floral hints, a bit earthy as well.  Surprisingly hoppy on first sip, and a lingering but pleasantly bitter finish.  Very nice beer on a hot day.
tap at taphouse. aroma was quite strong with vanilla and fruits. taste is sweet with apples and finishes quite hoppy.
Tap. Great beer. Aromas of apple, and vanilla. Taste is sweet, with a touch of acidity, and long lasting. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Yellow, with a frothy head.

Bottle from Cavie.  Pour is a very murky, opaque yellow with a white head.  Aroma is lemon, yeast, orange, and soda fizz.  Taste is orange juice pulp, heavy yeast, very dry, and dark spice.  Finish is super dry.

Bottle via trade.  Fairly clear orange color with some floating sediment.  Lasting white head.  Nice aroma of banana, spice, light grain and flowers.  Flavor has quite a bit of dry spice, bitter floral stem and milkweed.  Finishes dry with a lasting flavor of dry flowers.

341 ml bottle from Premier Wine & Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a very cloudy mildly brownish orange with a decent-sized rocky white head and lots of floating particles.  Yeasty aroma with lots of fruit (banana, a little lemon and peach) spice and green, earthy hops.  Taste is similarly fruity and yeasty with fairly mild spicing and a decent hoppy bitterness in finish.  Very enjoyable.

33 cl bottle.  Murky golden color, large thick white head, solid lacing.  Aroma of white bread and subtle orange peel.  Taste is yeasty, lots of malt, bitter orange in the middle and the finish.  Nice body.  Decent.

Aroma:Sweet, malty, and floral. Also I get some caramel.

Appearance:Golden in color, some floaty bits from the bottle conditioning. Nice head. Poor lacing.

Taste:Deep earthy flavors. Slightly spicy. This beer tastes like the inside of a lemonhead candy (once youve gotten past the sour outer coating).

Palate:Surprisingly thick mouthfeel on this one.

Overall:This is spot on in terms of style, and is really pleasant to drink. Easily sessionable.
Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a white head.  Nose is very yeasty with fruit, some spice, and subtle malts.  Medium body, sweet to start with more yeast, fruit, and subtle spicing.

Aroma of lemongrass, honey and coriander. Appearance is cloudy, unfiltered gold with white foamy head. Flavor matches the nose, with a pine hop presence in the finish. Palate was bubbly and creamy. Well done for the style, with surprising hop character.
Not sure about this one. It was not bad but the mix didnt work. The hops were a little out of balance and lacked the hop flavor just had bitter.  Serving: Bottle

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2010 J viens de goutté à cette bière...et jai bien aimé. La couleur ressemble à plutôt à une bière blanche. Bon résultat pour une bière de micro-brasserie. Je préfère la bière Trappiste Orval!

(Bottled, sampled 2010-02-08) Clear golden with a medium, lacy and lasting head. Yeasty, pale-malty, fruity, berryish, flowery-herby, slightly saisony aroma. Spicy flavor with pale malt, some honey and tartness, grassy-herby hops. Like La Chouffe, but smoother. Medium to full body, very soft CO2. A very well-balanced, soft, but complex and saisony blonde. Really a nice one!

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2015 Bouteille 341 ml. 6.5%. 2011 - 7 %. 2014 7%. Couleur jaune paille, un peu voilée,  mousse blanche. Effervescence vive. Nez dagrume et citron avec un peu dherbes fraîches.. Goût de houblons, agrumes et un peu de levures. Notes dalcool timides. Finale en amertume et arrière goût amer. IPA Belge. Très bonne.

341ml bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a slight orange hue and a big rocky white head that retains nicely. Complex notes of spice, fruit and grain on the nose with a little added sweetness on the palate and a long even finish. Top notch.

341 ml bottle. Finland.
Hazy yellow golden colour with small white head. Lots of sediment floating around. Belgian yeast and darkish earthy bitter hops in aroma. Mildish malty and dark bitter hoppy flavour. Surprisingly mild flavour.
Bouteille 33cl. Bière dont le fruité est mal équilibré, un peu acide pas trop de corps, notes de blé ? Une bière plutôt faible pur cette brasserie, il en ressort une belge très quelconque.

Served this little devil in a Val-Dieu glass.  It poured a hazy yellow with a two finger white head.  It has a yeasty, malty taste with notes of citrus and fruit.  I dont know what kind of fruit, maybe grapefruit and banana peel laced with spices.  Pretty sure theres some kind of Northern European flower taste thrown in to confuse me.  A pretty standard Belgian blonde.  Overall not a bad example of a style I dont drink too often...

Bottle. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy and yasty fantastic well-balanced aroma. Nice fruity esters present. Moderate bitter nice fruity flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Excellent belgian Ale.

Not the worst belgian style blonde, but still pretty good. Yeasty, malty, sweet caramel, fruity esters and nice toffee. Taste is very malty, yeasty and tons of complex fruity esters. Hard hitting beer. Quite good though.

335ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
7 lovely sweet fruity aroma, mandarin in the clear one, softer and breadier in the cloudy one but I prefer the crispness
3 pale orange, ring head. one we pourd clear, one cloudy.
7 cloudy, its a touch sludgy and yeasty. fairly standard yeast belgian, a bit soapy. clear one  is all round crisper, with more citrus bite.
4 cloudy one had soft carbonation, smooth palate, and a yeasty gingery and citrussy finish. clear one crisper, and with a crisp peach finish. both leave a lovely hoppy late finish.
14 pretty solid belgian ale - very true to the belgian style. in some ways more of a saison than a blond, but thats because it tastes so fresh, even though its been in finland al least 5 months.

The hop impact on this beer is unusually high for a Belgian ale. Whilst  bit out of place its certainly attractive; very pretty and floral on the nose and more bitter and pepperty in the mouth. Matches up well. The head on this beer is a treat; massively billowing fluffy white. Belgian IPA perhaps?

341ml bottle in tulip glass. pours hazy orange with a big white head that lasts and leaves lacing. aroma is citrus, coriander, banana peel and spices. taste is grapefruit, yeast,  lots of spices and hops in the finish. a very dry finish i might add. a good beer, not great.

11.5 oz bottle. Pours a large fluffy, white head of medium duration, with extensive lacing, over a cloudy, heavily sedmented, golden (SRM 6) body.....nose is light banana, peach, apricot, bit of floral hops.....taste is light sweet malts to start, leading to light floral tones, finishing with hop bitterness.....mouth feel is medium to light, carbonation high. This is a good example of a Belgian Blond Ale. It has some fruit/floral aromas, but also has the nice touch of hop presence. BJCP 7/2/14/4/7

Bottled. Pours nearly clear, golden amber with suspended sediments and a very large head. Taste is medium bitter and lightly sweet. Palate has medium carbonation and thick feel. Aromas have berries, pine, grass. A drop of yeasty sediments mellows the aromas a bit.

Pours a very hazy straw with quite a bit of sediment. I shouldve decanted this one slower. Big foamy head and active carbonation.  Nose of grapes, bread, raisins. Luscious and creamy while still being a bit thin, smooth and rounded, nice hint of sour and tart fruit and only slightly yeasty. Moderate bitterness but finishes clean.  Tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2011 12oz bottle, not sure where it came from? Pours a hazy orange-gold with a massive off-white, meringue head and tons of lacing. Pretty tame aroma that hints at Belgian yeast and some flowers. Nice flavor that has more floral notes plus a little spice. Well done.
An OK belgian ale. I think this beer is not for me. This beer is soft and somewhat sour and sometimes sweet. Very enticing beer. Try it if you like Belgian Ales.

pour creamy yellow with good foam on top. esters and belgian yeasts dominate the nose. bananas and dough notes mixed with flowers and hoppy notes, some spices that are nutmeg like in there as well. Great stuff. Belgian esters follow on the palate, slightly hoppy... I seem to remember this being more vegetal and hoppy than this one. big carbonation on the palate and some lees/syrop flavors in there as well. Good stuff, ONE of my all time favs from this brewery.

A golden and cloudy pour.  A big white gold soapy head.  Floating sediment.   A nice fruit, sweet spices, and yeast aroma.  Flavor is similar but offers more hops than the nose would hint at.  Nice peppery spice, deep resonant bitterness.  It took a bit for fruit to show up but then it added a super component to the flavor profile.  That fruit is beyond complex and is all over the board.  Oranges, tangerines, peaches, etc., and that fruit builds to the finish mixing with the spicy hops.  Is there a better brewer in the country of Canada?

Thought I drank all of these but that changed when a pair of bottles rolled out from under the front seat of my car this morning - I almost crashed as one wedged behind my brake pedal. Huge white bubbly cap on the pour, partially from a vigorous swirl of bottoms, cloudy light orange / amber beer with the finest white silty sediment I think Ive ever seen. Tons of sloppy sticky lacing. Up front aroma with a very interesting Belgian yeast spice and crazy fruity citrus and resin hops that meld into an amazingly unique aroma. Cloves and lemon and apricots. The taste is also very good making this amazingly easy to suck back. Just as you are about to get a dose of yummy yeast (.25 seconds in) an avalanche of hops crushes and buries the crummy red Datsun you are driving on the way home from a Bikram Yoga class. Resin, apricots, oranges and lemons were the culprits. Add in the spicy yeast, a hint of anise and biscuit after things quiet down - by the way, those hops did not ruin this interesting mix. Impressive  amounts of soft carbonation early on made drinking this even better. Good shit but pretty expensive.

Mouthfeel and appearance was consistent with style.  Although it was disclosed in the description, I still thought that the hopping was a bit overdone (dry hopped or as part of boil)... almost had a Barleywine-line quality to it.  Dieu du Ciels brewers never disappoint and this was still an excellent beer.
From a bottle. Not sure how valid my rating on this beer is, as Belgian/wheat beers are my least favorite style. So if you like this style beer, ignore my rating!

341mL bottle.  Pours clear bright gold with a small head that settles to a ring.  Earthy yeast, spicy and acidic fruity aroma.  Mild sweetness and medium bitterness, fruity acidity with floral and grassy hop flavour.  Light-medium bodied, lively carbonation with a bitter and drying finish.

11.5oz bottle. Pours a cloudy orange-gold colored body with a fluffy, finger-width, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of lacing. Aroma is full of spices and Belgian yeast, yet very fruity with plenty of orange peel, citrus, and tropical fruits. Clove, white pepper, and a light ginger make up the spices. Malts are lighter and sweeter with some candi sugar and a splash of honey. Flavor is similar with more of a pronounced spiciness. Lots of Belgian yeast and pepper up front. The orange peel, citrus, and tropical fruits come in along with a light, sweet malt to balance nicely. Ginger and clove mix their way in as well as some florals and honey. Finishes spicy, yet sweet with a noticable, dry, moderate bitterness that leaves a lengthy aftertaste. Medium body with a higher, soft carbonation that drinks nicely. Overall, another solid beer from these guys. Fruity and spicy with a balanced sweetness. I like the hopping on this too, being that its noticable, but far from distracting. Good one.

Appearance: hazy blond bordering orange (like an american wheat beer) with a nice 2 finger foam head that quickly dissipates and leaves behind some patchy lacing.

Smell: Lots of yeast and citrus. The smell is quite Belgian but it also reminds me of many of the Unibroue Belgian Style brews. Sweet pale malts, spicy but soft yeast, and lots of orange goodness. Intoxicating smell!

Taste: Grain up front, yeast in the middle, and some hop bitterness in the finish. Some floral qualities from the yeast, some orange and lemon qualities and hop bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Fairly thin with a decent amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Pretty good due to the mouthfeel.

Im liking this brew but my liquor store charges $6 for a 11.5oz bottle and I wont be returning to it at that price.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-23-2008

Bottle. Pours hazy orange, creamy white head. Aroma of spices, ruby grapefruit, nectarines, light bread dough. Taste is full of spices upfront - white pepper, coriander, bay leaf. Sharp citrus on top of more rounded orange flavours. Bitter medicinal finish. Good flavours , but out of balance a little for mine - a little more malt or dank or not so much hop would have worked better for me.

12 oz bottle. poued into Lost Abbey Stemware golden with a very thick white head that lingering for quite a while.  fruity aroma with nice belgian notes. flavor starts on the fruity side with strong apricot notes. finish has floral hops and firm biterness, lingering for a while . well balenced and very drinkable. if this was cheaper and redily available, Id drink it all the time. Or perhaps i need to just start mixing alesmith lil devil and IPA.

Pours pale amber with a lively small streams of carbonation feeding an impressive head and lacing.
Nose is very fruity with white grapes, peaches and pears. Add to that some spicy, herbal hops and phenols and you have quite a complex yet light brew.
Flavours are equally fruity with more grapes and pears along with more of those cloves. Unfortunately the bitterness is harsh, sharp and 1-dimensional.
Light body with moderate carbonation suit the beer well.

Bottle. Slightly hazy golden orange pour with a creamy white head that lasts a little while. Aroma has notes of yeast, caramel, citrus, bubblegum and spice. Flavour is very similar, a little less funky and a little sharper, with the citrus really standing out. Light, dry mouthfeel with high carbonation and a lingering bitter finish. Overall this is a really good Belgian style blonde ale, classical in style but original enough to stand out, and as good as any I have tried that are actually made in Belgium.
Reminded me of  a cultured Leffe Blonde. Much more delicate, but with bubblegum and banana coming to the fore, with a nice hoppy finish. Really well made for what it is.
Bottle. Golden- orange colour with a white head. Aroma is citrus, apricot, alcohol. Flavour is dry, malt, hop, citrus, sugar, apricot, alcohol. Nice beer.

11.5 oz bottle.  Cloudy orange with lots of floatie bits topped with a frothy bone head.  Nose is yeasty toffee and rose hips.  Creamy with crisp carb; nicely drinkable but still substantial.  Taste is slightly sour apricot and honey with a dry herbal finish.  Great example of an abbey blond.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 Mille bouteilles depuis sa fracassante création.  Une offrande sublime lorsque fraîche.  Une levure accaparante et des houblons vigoureux.  Des fruits et des fleurs.  Des épices?  Sans doute.  Tout compte fait, une proposition à faire plier les genoux.  Jadore sa très grande buvabilité et sa finale parfumée.  Une conception artistique.  Maintenant au sommet de mon court palmarès.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2010 Location: Bottle at Hop Devil Belgian Beer Room, 5/14/10


Aroma: The nose is tons of orange, some floral and other citrus notes

Appearance: Somewhat cloudy golden-orange color, with a big fluffy white head and lots of lace

Flavor: The taste on this one is somewhat sweet, with a decent hop presence too

Palate: It is a medium bodied beer, with a creamy mouthfeel, and a soft carbonation

Overall Impression: 
This one is pretty nice overall.  A strong orange presence is the leading component of this beer.  It seems to be rather dominant.

Bottle. Pours cloudy gold with a staunch, white head. Nose holds a good deal of malts, along with some earthy hops, some cloves and peppery spice. A rather sweet, malty character enhanced with some floral and resiney hops towards the end. Supporting roles played by light fruits, spices, Belgian yeast. Pretty nice. Fits the style I have noticed of most Dieu du Ciel beers, that is to say good, above all, but also marked by a certain spiciness and malt/hop balance that they routinely achieve.

Bottle.  Honey colored body, hazy, topped with a big, creamy head off-white in color, coating the glass with thick rings of sticky lace.  The aroma is very floral, spicy, lightly sweet and with citrus, and apricot notes.  Mouth is medium with foamy carbonation, on the dry side.  Flavor is lightly sweet with sugar, lightly spicy, big hop flavor of citrus, grapefruit, some pine, some apricot, and a long aftertaste of pine/citrus.  This brew smells lovely, looks lovely, and is pretty decent in the mouth as well.  Reasonably refreshing, surprisingly hoppy and good.  The malt profile is English, the yeast is belgian, and the hopping is West Coast.

341ml bottle misty orange pour decent carbonation rapid in the glass aromas spice yeast fruit earthyness clove  flavour coriander orange yeast very smooth ale lemon light gentle bitter a little creamy aftertaste bitter sweet perhaps lacks  a little body
Hazy golden straw body with short but lasting head. Aroma is sweet, malty and a little bit of yeast. Taste is fairly simple so very easy to drink, hints of apricot plus a little bready.

Dieu Du Ciel
Derniere Volante
Pours hazy golden with a thick billowy head and nice retention. Mild lacing. Sweet aroma of Belgian yeast, spicy citrus fruit, and a mild floral hop note. Flavor is extremely well balanced with a citrus fruitiness and a nice hop finish. Good beer, and as usual Dieu Du Ciel rocks.

Bottle. A hazy, orange-golden beer topped by a dense, white head. Peppery, resiny nose with apricot, white sugar and some alcohol. Alcohol, peppery hops and some apricots in the flavor, leading to a bitter, resiny finish. Full-bodied and effervesecent. A nice beer, especially enjoyed the peppery touch. 091127
Hazy orange with massive white head. Heavy aroma of citrus, high clove and spice. Flavor of tropical fruit, grassy hops. Bitter, dry finish

Picked this and peche mortal up at Stateline Liquors in MD. Poured into my Chimay Chalice.

A- Pours with a 1/2 finger creamy white head that has perfect retention. Body is a beautiful translucent gold. Cloudiness is very dense and yeast sediment can be seen floating throughout along with bubbles steadily rising to the top.

S- Nose is soft and floral hops, peppery spice. and sweet yeast are detectable with a light scent of fruits too. Very nice.

T- Dry apple, pear, and citrus upfront with a soft,smooth, yeasty backbone. Bitter floral hops and a good dose of peppery spice kick in for the finish and do not overpower what was already present. Soft hop bitterness and all the characteristics mentioned before linger on the back of the palate long after each swallow.

P-Medium to high carbonation and a light smooth and yeasty body.

O- Well here you have it. I havent sampled much from this style considering we like our big beers-and BSPA is my favorite style. The other pale Abbey Ales I have tried dont measure up to this one though. This has everything I like about BSPAs and Tripels w/o as much Alcohol...therefore perfect drinkability. French Canadians sure do know how to make their Belgians.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-06-2008 00:04:49

Bottle shared by AndyReynolds. 
Yeah Im not really sure what is going on here.  Light aroma and flavor.  Nothing special stands out at all.  Contains a dry earthiness, maybe some fruit, and dust.  Just not much going on and has a thin, light body.

Cloudy amber with a generous foamy head that laces and lasts. A very nice light fruity aroma comes from the bottle. The flavor is also fruity with some sweetness up front, a touch of tart and then a bitter finale. Quite dry with a very nice after taste. This is another winner from these guys.

The aroma is citrus, hops, but dominated by lemon. The appearance is cloudy lemonorange with a huge creamy, frothy head. The bready wheat  flavor starts out with some subtle spice. It is smooth with subtle sweet wheat flavors on the palate.

Bottle.  Aroma is yeast and sweet malts.  Dark fruits, bananas, and bread notes stand out.  Palate is rather light.  The bready/doughy flavor comes out in the taste.  I have become somewhat of a fan of Dieu du Ciel, but this one kind of let me down.  It is a good beer, but nothing that stands out.

341 ml bottle froma trade with fred82 shared with jessem. pours a hazed golden with a white cap. great aroma of fresh tropical from, yesty esters, great belgian blonde aroma. the flavour are a little bit of a let down after the aroma. super dry and well hopped but there was a husky wheatiness that knocked this down a notch. still a great beer andone id buy regularily, if i could. thx fred!

Bottle shared with matt7215, thanks for the share Matt. This stuff poured a hazy gold with a medium white head. The aroma was absolutely out of this world, orgasmic even. Loads of floral hops, lots of peach, mango, pale malt and dry yeast. I could sniff it all day. Flavour has some good citrusy hops upfront with accompanying sweet pale malt, dry yeast in the finish with a good dry hop bite. Some dull wheat malt as well. Very simple and elegant. Almost more enjoyable to smell than to taste. I could session this stuff all day, thanks again for the share Matt.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2010 Hazed golden orange w/ a ton of particulates, white head of small bubbles and good splotches of lace. Nose is tart citrus with a hint of vanilla creaminess. Delicate and refreshing. Very dry w/ just a little tartness. Light bodied w/ vigorous carbonation. Crisp finish w/ just a touch of bitterness. A very fine Belgian blond. 

Here is a rerate of this stuff that I accidentally put in w/ the barrel aged version. After reading the commercial description, my rating speculates as to what the barrel aging added to what ultimately was a beer w/ no barrel aging. Oh well. My total score came out exactly the same and to my credit, I did note vanilla notes in the original rating. Here goes: I am not certain but Im pretty sure this is the first beer Ive had that was aged in wine barrels. It is the only one I remember anyway. (And I pretty much have to remember it as Im drinking it right now.) Its a decent cloudy orange color but the head is short lived and consists of large, soapy bubbles rather than my preferred, tight knit creamy head. The nose is mild, Belgian in character, w/ a sort of bitter oak and vanilla note in the background. This oaken note becomes stands out much more once the beer is tasted and is what I presume the pinot noir barrel adds. Its quite nice w/ good depth of flavor. The texture is light but still somewhat creamy w/ the carbonation prickling only faintly. This is a very well done beer in which the barrel character really compliments rather than dominates.
The aroma has notes of citrus and spice, maybe a little bit of lemon and orange. The color is hazy and dark with orange tints. Very smooth and tasty.

11.5 oz bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a Trappist glass. Pours clear golden with a tall off-white head and large particles of sediment. Head mostly fades but leaves some lace. Aroma is intense English hops and toasted malts. Notes of apple, spice and yeast also present. Flavour is dry malts blending with bitter hops. Finish is long and bitter. On the palate, light in body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. This beer contains elements of both Belgian and English ales, exactly as its brewer describes. The aroma is reminiscent of an abbey ale, with additional English hops. The flavour and finish become progressively more IPA-ish, closing with intense dry-hopping. Overall, Im not so sure it works out. A well-appreciated experiment though. 2010-04-08

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a hazy gold with plenty of visible sediment, mostly at the bottom, and a soft eggshell white head that leaves a lot of sloppy lacing in the glass.  Aroma of spice, yeast, tropical fruits, ginger, pepper, wet paper, and honey.  Flavor of yeast, tropical fruits and a hint of berries, spices, pepper, pale and sweet malts, honey, and candi sugar.  Medium-bodied, with fairly gentle carbonation and a chewy mouthfeel.  Sweetness and bitterness both linger on the aftertaste.  Pretty solid; Im really digging everything Ive had from DDC so far.
12 oz bottle. Pale yellow and hazy. Belgian yeast, light spicing. Soft is the key note here.Very low alcohol flavors. Fluffy mouth and too drinkable. Nice.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 11.5oz bottle poured into a shaker.  This beer pours hazy with "Yippie"-sized head.  The color is yellow-orange and hazy.  The aroma is wonderfully fruity and refreshing with tangerines banana and yeast being most prominent.  The flavor is also fruity.  It has lots of acid, floral tastes and carbonation.  It takes a few sips to settle into the flavor but once you do it is quite nice.  The body is medium in heaviness and a lemony after taste rounds out the drink.  If you dont like the bitter pulp in your juice, you might not like this beer.
A blond color beer with an extremely huge head. The aroma was alcohol, grains, sweet. The taste was very floral, spicy, with a bitter ending.

12oz Bottle, purchased at Zenos Pub - State College, PA. Interesting musky spice and yeast aroma. Some wet bretty cardboard and a snap of ginger. Mellowed and peppery. Pours a good haze of deep golden and a solid fluffy off-white head. Flavors follow suit, with chewier versions of the aroma. Some pecan, a nip of banana paste, and carrot sugar. This is fairly simple, straightforward and enjoyable ale with a unique blend of malt flavors and yeast. Theres some old hop dust that doesnt work for me, but it is what it is. In retrospect, I wouldnt have paid the $8.50 I was gouged for this in Pennsylvania.

Bottle...  Poured a hazy, vibrant golden/orange with a white head.  Aroma of candied sugars, esters, floral hops.  Lots going on here, with notes of citrus, sugary malts, apricots, and a nice spice balance like cloves and other herbs.
Pours cloudy yellow with a large white head. Aroma is malt, light fruit and banana notes. Flavour is malt, light grassy hop, fruity and banana.
bottle.  Pours a cloudy gold with an off-white head.  Nose is slightly lemon and yeast.  Flavor is mild.  Not what I was hoping for.  Some flowers.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin.  Nothing special.

Hazy golden orange colour with particles floating around. Aroma is spices, caramel and some mild wood. Flavour is wood, spices, some earth and mild herbal notes as well.

Bottled 0,341l at Beer Hunters
Hazy blond yellow color, small white head. Belgian style yeasty fruity (mango, peach) aroma. Yeasty, fruity (peach, mango), spicey (white pepper) and hoppy flavor. Very Belgian. Enjoyable. Lots of yeast in the bottom.
Bottle. Hazy orange body, with a medium White head. Aroma is spices, chocolate biscuits?? Flavor is spices, yeast, notes of hops.

Pours to a murky stained pine colored body with a tall, super foamy rocky off-white head.  Superb lacing.  The aroma has a subtle grain dust amongst a plantain and strong yeasts.  Perhaps a light mandarin orange?  Pine resin.  The flavor is yeasty but pretty spicy.  Perhaps white peppercorns.  Some pine hops.

Cloudy, murky, sediment filled straw color w/ a huge frothy white head with sticky lacing.
