A lot of prickly carbonation, light in body, very drinkable.

11.5 oz. Hazy peach-amber with a medium-sized, lasting and creamy head. Sweet clove-banana, resin, citrus peel, and pepper aroma. Flavor is the same components, but sort of proportionally reversed and not as sweet as the smell would indicate: more resin, citrus, pepper, and wood to provide a nice balance to the sweet malt. Near medium body is fairly smooth and dry.

330 ml bottle. Hazy gold color with a three-finger, semi-rocky white head. Aroma is coriander, yeast, bit of pepper, and maybe hop and malt. Maybe. Medium body with smooth and creamy carbonation. Flavor: Picking up spice and a touch of banana. Hint of pepper. Floral hop. Tingles the tongue. Finishes absolutely balanced and delicious. Very fine drinking. Is everything these folks brew this good?

Bottle from Foodery, Philly, PA.  Chimay glass.    Nice blonde golden color with great small bubble head and great retention.  Hazy.  Floral, spicy, fruity, honey, and slightly herbal aroma.  More fruit and spice oriented upon tasting.  Honey sweetness.  Well nuanced and balanced.  Soft and pleasant palate.  But somewhat astringent finish.   I would love to try this again.

11.5 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy gold body with a big and fluffy light-tan head that leaves plenty of lacing.  A subtle floral aroma that features hints of bananas and vanilla.  Medium-bodied.  A smooth, sweet start with vanilla upfront.  Finishes with a biscuity dryness.  Yeasty, herbal qualities and some pepper throughout.

Bottle from Keg Liqour. Poured hazy yellow color with a large white head that lasted with good lacing. Very complex  herbs and sour citrus aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Full complex spicy bittersweet flavor with solid sour citrus finish of moderate duration. Very good brew.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2010 Pours a clear gold with good white head.   Sweet caramel malts, biscuits, spice, banana, apricot, honey, floral hops, and some bitterness.  Fruit, citrus, a bit of lemon zest, and some funkiness.  This is an excellent, complex brew.  Well Done!

Pours golden color with slight haze and light head with great lacing.  No yeast or other particulates.  Spicy bready aroma with light flowery hops.  This beer is full of hop bitterness and very well balanced. Carbonation leaves a nice prickly finish.  I like this one a lot and would gladly have another.

Bottle courtesy of Tupalev, thanks Jeff!-This Belgian Ale is hazy yellow with lots of yeast floaties throughout showing right after thew pour. The head is a frothy, rocky cap and leaves nice lace. In the nose, lemon rind and funky yeast meet bread crust and flowery hops, with a touch of spicy pine. This beer shows good flavours of lemongrass and floral hops, leading into yeasty funk and quite dry hops. Finish is dry and bitter. This is well made and dangerously drinkable given the ABV. Thanks a lot for this one Jeff!

I was disappointed here in that the underlying structure of this beer was set up so perfectly--very dry and quite bitter.  What was needed was just a hint of malt sweetness and this thing would be amazing.  But I never found any sweetness.  It really saddened me, because the base of this beer has so much potential.  All framing and not enough substance, I should say.  I really want to give this beer another shot, because maybe I just missed something.

Slghtly cloudy gold, thin white head. Bready, spicy, slightly winey aroma. Flavor is surprisingly dry - crackery and black pepper, some champaigne, with a lot of crisp hop bitterness. Very tasty and refreshing.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2008 Pours a hazy, coppery, golden color with a full, white, creamy, and rocky; longevity of the head is good and settles to a very small, rocky layer leaving random lace.  Nose is simple but pleasant; notes of honey, doughy yeast, spicy notes of white pepper (maybe from the dry-hooping), lemongrass, and coriander.  Flavor is certainly dry-hopped but not overdone; spicy notes of white pepper, coriander, lemongrass, orange zest, malty notes of honey and toasted grains, light doughy yeast and hints at cloves.  Palate is soft to lively, medium, creamy, and lightly dry.  Finishes fairly lengthy with the moderately bitter notes remaining throughout leaving only some citrus notes, grass, clove, and pepper in the end.  A nice, fairly easy-drinking light Belgian; it is well put together but there is nothing exceptional about it.
Solid Belgian.  Nice palate with light carbonation.  Yellow color and a bit o head.  Banana with some spices, perhaps clover.  Slightly bitter finish. (on tap at Dieu du Ciel, Montreal)

This Belgian Ale pours a deep yellow gold color from a 33cl bottle. Very large sized creamy white head, with excellent staying power and lacing. The aroma is fruity and sweet, with some yeast and hops. A medium bodied Belgian Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, with some yeast and spice. The hops are piney and citrusy. Nice balance. The beer starts out fruity and sweet and finishes dry and hoppy. There are some Belgian yeast and breadiness in the middle. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet with a touch of hop bitterness.

Bottle from Belmont Station--Poured a hazy golden body, slightly orange, with a fluffy thick white head.  Sweet, yeasty, hoppy nose.  Citrus and floral with tart and malty undertones.  Somewhat amazing.  I really, really enjoyed sipping on this beer.  I wish I had more now.

It poured a slightly hazed golden body, tinged with orange and capped by a large, pillowy head that laced the glass heavily.  The aroma is quite floral, yeasty, with plenty of citrus fruit beneath it all.  The malty sweetness provides a good balancing factor in a flavor sominated by a citric tartness and and floral bitterness that grows as the drinking goes on.  The finish is dry and mildly bitter.  Quite nice.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Downers Grove, IL<font size=-1>

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 cloudy dark gold with a large white foamy head.  apricot, flowers, spices, pepper, apple aroma.  flavor is peach, apricot, rose hips, hops, pepper, herbs.   nice and floral.  very impressed with this brewery.

5/22/08.  12 oz bottle thanks to drewbeerme.   Pours a hazed orange color with a tall fluffy white head.  The nose has a creamy doughy yeastiness to it with lemons and florals.  Sweet and slightly creamy flavors.  Citrus, grass, with a touch of spice.  The finish is rather drying but tasty.

This was cloudy golden in color with a thick fluffy white head.  Aromas are of florals, spice, herbs, citrus and yeast.  In the mouth it is medium-bodied with a concentrated and crisp, yet rich, midpalate that fades to some dry bitterness on the finish.

Bottle at tasting at Chris Fischers (from Liars Club) house. Pours with a gold body topped by a thin to medium thick head with a good amount of lacing. Its slightly sweet yet bitter wtih notes of grass and some spices.  Light to medium bodied and dry.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2010 Pours hazy orange with a large sudsy off-white froth... very foamy.  Strong fruity, spicy, herbal aroma.  Smells sweet and French.  Bubbly but still smooth and creamy mouthful,slightly rough.  Not as sweet as it smells.  Some candy malt, sour funk, and lots of yeast in the flavor.  The dry hopping is quite unique and works excellently with the yeast.  Long peppery finish.  Well balanced, and a very well made beer... just not enough going on to be great.  ???  - No idea what Im talking about here.... French? dont think it had any sour funk...o yikes

Light golden color with a full, wispy head of foam.  Authentic Belgian smell, some dough, light fruits, farmhouse character.  Quite vibrant.  Lots of taste, with expressive citrus and herbal hop notes, hints of fruits.  Nice Belgian character as well.  Very full bodied.  An impressive brew.

Golden yellow pour with large rocky white head thick like meringue. Bubbles are large soda bubbles. Very sticky large lacing. Hops really shine through at first, very herbal almost peppery nobel type hop aroma. Below that there is a nice subtle fruity ester and maybe a hint of citrus followed by a faint alcohol note. I am quite impressed with the complexity in the nose. Wow the taste does not dissapoint. This one really wakes up the palate. Spicey tart and sweet all seem to exist nearly simultaneously. A nice bitter, spicey, herbal hop note leads the charge, followed quickly by a pleasant citrus note coupled with a mild sweetness. The whole thing ends up rolling towards the hops toward the end. This is very big yet well balanced. I agree with marcbe in that the bitter and tart characteristics blend like Orval or even a Westy blonde. Well done to say the least and way under-rated in my opinion.

Bottle poured a clear golden yellow with a lasting white head. Aromas of straw, honey, fruittiness, spice and light earthiness. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, pears, light spice and a hint of earthiness with a smooth dry lingering bitter finish.

Bottle, Cloudy pale straw color with creamy white head that create a lot lacing. Hop first, then yeast, malt and fruit. Strong hop flavor, citrus (grapefruit) and caramel. Reminds me of Orval which can only be good.
Pours cloudy yellow with a tall white head. Wit nose and flavor, citrus and coriander, crisp finish. Hops add a fruity floral nice and citrus flavor. Dry finish, very refreshing, spicy finish.
Another solid beer from this brewery.  Pours a hazy gold with a thick off white head.  Nice aroma of spices, yeast, and some citrus.  Well balanced, the spices worked out well.  Well done.

12oz single bottle purchased for $2.29 from Metro Joanette (probably) in Montreal.   Pours a perfect cloudy light gold with good head.  Fabulous aroma of hops and yeast.  The taste doesnt quite live up to the smell though.  First sensation is tanginess on the tongue, and the beer goes down with yeastiness and some spice.  Quite nice.

1/24/08 notes:  bottle, pours light apricot. Intense floral, spice, hops, maybe even pumpkin in head. Medium carbonation for a Belgian, with sugary touch similar to Unibroue but more subdued.  Great balance, and truly unique blend of spices, cinnamon, nutmeg? Great, especially for a beer not my favorite style!)

Courtesy TheCheeseMan.  Cloudy dark yellow color, even white sopay head.  Slightly sweet grainy aroma, mild floral notes, slight Belgian cast.  Taste is slight earthy hops with some residual sweetness.  Mild Belgian yeasty tastes.  Quality, but not outstanding.

12 oz bottle at Uber Tavern in Seattle, Washington.  Pour is a very cloudy cheddar cheese orange with a thinnish white head. Aroma of Belgian yeasty spiciness. Some cloves come through to. Taste is a bit funky, with very drying spiciness. Some citrus peel. Finish is drying. Overall, reminded me a bit of Fantome with the yeast and spiciness.

Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately to heavily hoppy (resin, herbs, grapefruit), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of pepper, gum, dried pineapple, alcohol.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Tainted by overly aggressive hops of the wrong variety, which threatens to clobber whats Belgian about it.  Pity, because otherwise its a solid beer.  I would expect this sort of treatment from a west coast American brewer, but DDC?  Odd.

Near cloudy golden body with a tall heavy cream colored head. Decent lace. Initial scents of dried flowers, vanilla and mild spices. Hops dominated the aromas in the beginning but as the volatiles are driven off  some milk caramel, light fruit and wheat lay underneath. Some light pencil eraser rubber seems to pop up and distract a touch. Very nice start with pale malt, mild rose and light coriander and touch of citrus. The spice and citrus take over in the middle and things become more acidic and "rough". The front is so soft and smooth. that the finish and linger are somewhat a letdown. Linger has thistle and weed flavors along with a touch of light pepper. Just nice.

11.5oz. Bottle:  Belgian yeast, coriander, spices, pepper, and herbs.  Poured amber/orange in color with a large, foamy, white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Many particles throughout.  Sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of yeast, herbs, pepper, coriander, and some bitter hops.  Medium body.  Tingly dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Dry hop, pepper, and yeast finish.

Bottle. Luckily I got this in Montreal for $1.50, because this is not worth close to the $4+ Americans have to pay. Pours with a ludicrous (and beautiful) white head. Full nose of tart hops and pils malts. Flavor is junky and boring though, lactic malts and spent yeast. The yeast signature just doesnt work for me in the flavor (as I find with most all DdC belgians). Needs more dough, more spice, more assertiveness, and a bit more attenuation. A most average beer.
Bottle. Golden amber beer with a nice off-white head. Floral aroma with some nice yeast and a bit of fruitiness. Yeasty, floral, bready flavor. Medium body. Pepper and a yeasty breadiness lingers.

[bottle] Hazy yellow/amber color. Very nice dense, white foam. Spicy hop aroma, lots of yeast esters. Flavors are sugary, sweet malt, spicy. Clove, fruit esters. Grassy, noble herbal hop flavor. Overall, quite good.

12 oz. twist off bottle. I fricking HATE twist offs. Hey Montreal, buy some decent bottles, you cheap bastards!
No freshness date seen. Poured out a hazy yellow color, with a sticky white head. Aromas are of Chicago Peace roses, very floral, and perfume like.
Some burnt yeast notes along with rotten pears round out the aromas.
Flavors are of sweet malts, rotten pears, burnt yeast. Medium mouthfeel, OK body. Nothing to write home about though, unless you like cheap twist off bottles.

Tasting - Perfect Pour - Hazed gold, creamy white head.  Floral banana and soft peppered coriander aromas ride undercurrents of grassy yeasty pear tones.       Spiced fruity wheat-like flavors mingle with hints of sugared bread and earthy grass.  Very well balanced from start to finish.  Medium bodied, fizzy carbonation, light peppery sweet finish.  A very nice summer brew....

Pours a hazy pale orange wheat color with a frothy, thick white head.  Pretty nice nose of wheat, perfumy (light) spices and pungent hops, a large presence of Belgian candy sugar and a very pleasent and enticing Belgian yeast aroma.  Medium thickness, frothy, wetting the palate instantly, its a delicious, light and fluffy yeast that works so well in this one... a touch of citrus and fruity hops and you have a damn nice beer.

Bottle from SL. Poured a pretty golden color, fairly clear (for a Belgian) with some haze, lots of carbonation on display, generous head, and good Belgian-esque lacing. The aroma was grassy, wheaty, fruity esters, spices. Flavor followed the aroma, bananas and cloves the fruit and spice, finishing clean with the grass making for a nice finish. Came across like a Strong Golden in malt, flavor depth, sweetness. Was expecting a lighter and dryer Belgian Ale, although this was nice.

bottle. Poured hazy golden with a huge white head that persists until the last sip. Lemongrass and wheat aromas up front, with some clove and hops. Wheat, yeast, and citrus flavors give way to earthy hops. Dry, mildly astringent finish.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a cloudy peach color, with a big fluffy white head. Very sticky lacing. Very inviting. Cider farmhouse aromas, with hazy mango, clove, and floral hops come through nicely. Malty texture on the tongue, with flavors of spicy wheat and grain. Nice hoppy finish. Dry, drinkable, and very refreshing.

Great beer. Bottle. Poured into Chimay goblet. Pours a beautful gold with nice frothy head. Spicy aroma full of coriander, herbal, floral, lavender?, hops. Taste is almost medicinal, herbal, peppery then hoppy. Finishes off with a nice sweet malt finish. Nice full creamy mouthfeel. Great beer. Shelton Brothers get this beer out there

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden with a thick long lasting white head that leaves great lacing. Aroma of spicy yeast, cloves, coriander, citrus, and floral hops. Taste is the same as aroma and finishes slightly grassy. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and a dry crisp spicy finish. Very good.

Pours a beautiful hazy peach-gold with a thick head that looks like beaten egg-whites. Aroma is full of promise - cloves, coriander, banana... yum. Oh god, Belgian blondes would ALL be immensely better if dry-hopped. This is totally the way to go! Wonderful crisp hop taste opens up into delicious malty sweetness perfectly balanced by lingering bitter hops, not grassy at all but lightly grapefruit-like. Notes of canned peaches. Alcohol warms the finish. Great creamy body, if a bit under-carbonated, but really quite nice. What a super treat - thanks to Robinvboyer for the trade!!!

UPDATED: APR 18, 2008 Bottle from robinvboyer. Poured a fairly clear and light orange with a powerful and huge white head. The aroma is spices, apple, and some citrus. The flavor is dominated by a zesty and spicy sweet malt, with tons of spices and a nice somewhat bitter hop finish. A very nice Belgian Ale. Less yeasty and more hoppy than most. I could drink a ton of this.

11.5oz bottle. Poured a deeper and cloudy yellow color with huge sized (5 finger) white head. Aromas of bananas, spices (lots of pepper), and yeast. Tastes of spices (lots of pepper again), fruity, some citrus, and yeast. Some lacing left on the glass.

Bottle from trip to Montreal. Slightly hazy golden with a large white head that leaves some beautiful lacing. Aroma is fantastic, big and fruity (esp. apricot), some sweet and spicy notes, good yeast character, and floral & tea-like hop notes. Full mouthfeel, a bit creamy. Flavour starts like a typical solid Belgian golden ale - yeast, fruit, a but of spice - but then the hops kick in and take it to the next level with lingering notes of orange zest. Excellent stuff!

12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy golden with orange notes and a larger foamy/bubbly white head that left sticky lacing.  Aroma of of pepper, lemon, orange peel, Belgian yeast, spicy, candi sugar, floral, fruity, and a nice hop touch.  Flavor was more of the up front black pepper, Belgian yeast spiciness, some tropical fruits, orange, bready, candi sugar, nice and dry.  Well done.

Pours a slightly hazy yellow gold with a frosty medium sized white head. Nice lacing.  Aroma of black pepper, zesty orange, yeast and sugar spice.  Taste is peppery with hints of of light candied sugar, zesty orange and yeast.  Nice.

Bottle.  Pours turbid dull golden with orangy edges and 2 fingers of fluffy, white head.  Aroma is rock sugary malt, floral spice, mild yeasty funk, orange zest, and black pepper.  THe taste is very black peppery, with a solid dose of orange zest, rock sugary malt, and floral yeast.  Finishes bone dry, and the complexity of flavor never diminishes.  This one is outstanding.

clear golden pour, good amount of white head. Great aroma if hops, belgian yeast, and citrus with a touch of banana. Flavour is very fruity, lots of citrus from the hops, and a touch of spice. Insanely drinkable, just a top notch amazing belgian ale!

Huge, very dense & fine, just-yellowish head over hazy golden beer with an orange to amberish shine; well-carbonated. Quite hoppy nose, C-hops, but not as overpowering as from an APA or IPA. Clearly dry-hopped, with a bit of ureum, and some citruspeel aromas. Nice. Very dry & hoppy flavour, in the taste noble UK hops, rather than C-one. Gently, nice crystal malt and toasted notes, lightly sweetish creep in, counterweighed by a citrussy fruitiness. Very balanced. Medium bodied & very slick, discreet alcohol warming. This kind of hoppiness will take another decennium to be called Belgian, I fear. In the mean time, the beer is beyond reproach.  Grand merci, Sylvain!

(Bottle)  Pours a hazy golden-amber with a large rocky creamy off-white head.  Aroma of herbs, plastic, mango, dried Turkish apricots, passion fruit, and biscuit.  Flavor of toasted oats, floral, pear, herbs, apple, and orange peel.  Nicely crafted and quite complex.
A golden hazy beer with a small white head. The aroma is bready malty with slight notes of smoke. Fllavour is sweet and spicy with coriander and candy sugar but also with a wheaty presence.

Bottle.  Nice golden yellow pour with a slight haze, good size fluffy white head with great lacing.  Very strong spicy aroma with some candy like sugar sweetness.  Wonderful taste!  Soft floral notes giving way to lots of spice, coriander and clove, and finishes with a sharp bitterness.  Incredible foamy soft mouthfeel really lets you take it all in and accentuates the flavours that are here.  Wow, this is really good.  I wish I had a chance to try this at the brewpub - I have never seen it on until the bottles came out.  Incredible;e, knocked my socks off.

Bouteille 341 ml, Mousse abondante qui reste (typique des bière belges). Couleur orange brulé trouble. Au nez on découvre des arômes dépices, de fleurs, dalcool, citron et houblon. En bouche la bière est moyennement ronde et elle nous offres des flaveurs dépices,  de levure fruité,  de houblons moyennement amers avec une touche dacidité.

341 mL bottle received via trade with Glouglouburp.  Pours clear orange with a large, frothy, white head, lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is average malt (hay, straw, meal), average hops (flowers, perfume), average yeast (soap, earth) with notes of dust.  Light bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a metallic finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

Name: Derniere Volonte
Date: 01/25/2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party

Appearance: hazy orange, fine off white head, streaks of drippy lace, 
Aroma: sweet malt candy aroma with nice balancing spicyness, 
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, nice fruity character, lots of spicyness add complexity and balance, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20

Bottle date 12/07

Pours hazy, pale gold, with a merange-like head of eggshell white.
The dense foam took several minutes before receding to a raised cone in the center.
Exceptional lacework throughout the glass, with ring after ring of whipped foam.
Aromatics are belgianesqe and somewhat hoppy.
Cloves, mint gum, and lemon zest, along with some peppery dryness.
The mouthfeel is light and well carbonated,
dry and crisp.
The pallet has very light malt, with a firm, dry bitterness, and a sligtly tart citric bite.
Alcohol is somewhat warming and does not detract.
Finishes bone dry with more lemon zest.
Very quenching and quaffable.

Of the six Dieu Du Ciels Ive tried recently, this one was far better than all but the Peche Mortel.

341 mL bottle from Jovi, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Hazy golden with a large off-white head.
  
Aroma:  Beautiful green, resinous, leafy, floral hops (yum!), a healthy dose of coriander behind that, honey and yeast, 
  
Palate:  Medium body, full effervescence that is a bit sharp in spots.
  
Flav.:  The burst of resinous, leafy, floral hops is followed by a soothing malt/honey/yeast feeling that is then followed by lemony coriander; on swallowing, there is admirable bitterness;  the beer is off-dry and there is no alcohol anywhere, dough and bread crust linger.

I love it.  Belgian-inspiration with aggressive hopping makes for a lovely beer.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 Hazy orange with a large head that lasts and coats the glass. Aroma is coriander, pepper, yeast, somewhat fruity. Medium bodied, high carbonation that somehow works. Typical flavors with high carbonation, kinda interesting. Nice appearance though.

Rerate: not a 5 for appearance. Dropped it down.

Bière blonde aux reflets ternes. Laisse un col moyen et persistant de couleur ivoire.
Parfum plutôt houblonné : aux notes dagrumes, de résine, dencens, de cuir et de lavande. Au premier abord, une note florale et savonneuse agaçante assaille le palais. Le goût par la suite est plus équilibré avec les agrumes et les résines. Il y a bien un petit goût de cuir, ce qui est un peu moins élégant. Larrière-goût est mieux : notes houblonnées, déthers et de levures. La bouche est mousseuse, ce qui nestompe pas les impressions savonneuses (désolé dinsister).
Jai bien apprécié les saveurs résineuses et dagrumes, elle rappelait une IPA avec une bonne dose de levures. Ce nest pas la bière que je demanderais comme « dernière volonté ».
Bottle, thanks to after4ever! Pours hazy gold with a lacy white head. Lemon and earth aroma, bread and lemon taste. Medium-light body and explosive carbonation. Woody dry finish.

330. Thanks, glouglouburp! Pours cloudy medium amber with golden highlights. Dense creamy white head. Huge sugary and lemony nose. Medium, slightly creamy body with tons of frothy fizz. Lemon pith, grass, sugar, and a tiny hint of pepper on the mid-palate. Clean, slightly dry finish. Great little beer I could drink the hell out of if it were more available.

Appearance: Pours a clear, yellow-orange body with a large, fizzy white head.

Smell: All the components of the aroma are certainly clear and distinct - banana, citrus, coriander, dough.

Taste: Banana bread dough mixture. Citric and exceptionally spicy throughout. Malts and even some sugary sweetness try to emerge but soon fade back into the spice. Bitter, hoppy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Sharp, prickly carbonation.

Drinkability: In an attempt to fit in more around these parts, Ive given more and more Belgian ales a try. Sadly, though, this one failed to win me over.

Pours a transparent golden bronze with a frothy, full-lacing off-white head.  Has a lightly sweet pale malty nose with some authentic biscuity Belgian yeasty notes.  Body starts semi-sweet and bready with some toasty maltiness and earthy bittering hop flavor toward a drier, bittersweet doughy finish.  An enjoyable and true to style Belgian Ale.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 Bouteille brune de 341 ml. Arômes fins dagrumes, de céréales et de houblon. Robe dorée et trouble, belle mousse crémeuse. Goût typique de levure belge et de houblon herbeux et citronné, présente également une touche épicée. Arrière-goût houblonné plutôt amer, avec une très légère touche dalcool.

12 ounce bottle from the Festivus Guy.  Pours lightly hazed golden with a sticky snow white head.  Good lacing.  Very hoppy.  Lemons and flowers.  A touch of banana, dough, and lemon scented cleaner.  The lemon cleaner come out in the flavor at lemon dish soap.  A little bit of the Belgian sugar sweetness.  Sharp bitter finish.  Medium body.  Softer mouthfeel.  Lower than expected carbonation.  Balanced finish.  Id perfer if drier.  Not bad though.

Pours a mostly clear, very lightly hazy golden blond color.  A small, foamy, densely packed head shows excellent retention and leaves some nice, patchy lacing behind on the glass.  The aroma is dry and crisp, with a surprising hoppy punch.  Soft citrus overtones meet a toasted bready, yeasty malt base, followed by pungent and spicy floral hops.  The flavor is equally complex, with the floral dry hopping obviously adding alot to the brew.  The citrus defines itself as a light orange and lemon chiffon blend, while the hops finish ultra-dry and bitter.  I swear I even pick up some brett in this, though Im not sure if that is the intention.  Medium-full, well carbonated mouthfeel.  Id like to know the IBU measure on this one, as it is indeed surprisingly hoppy.  Solid brew.  Really well done for a delicate, light Belgian style.  I could definitely go for a few of these on a hot Florida day.

341 mL bottle (Nov 07).  Labelled at 6.5%.  Hazy copper-orange with a small white head that faded to a film.  The aroma is great; everything you want in a Belgian with the appealing addition of fresh hops.  The flavour is quite complex: fruit (green apple, maraschino cherry), herb and spice (especially pepper), and a bit of alcohol.  Quite a bitter finish, for the style.  Dry finish.  Full  body, medium carbonation.
Bottled. A lot of foam. Spicy but not too much, with agrumes, belgian yeast, warmy but refreshing. Overall a good belgian ale.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 341ml bottle, bottled 11/07. thanks to Glouglouburp for this one. pours hazy golden with white head. nose is pretty spiced up with coriander, cloves, yeasty. flavors is of mild sweet belgian candy sugar, some yeast, citrus and mild banana, herbal hops. extremely drinkable, lively carbonation, smooth light body. long mildly sweet finish. awesome stuff. really wish i had more.4.0 

5/22/08, bottle. a spicy, herbal, floral aroma. flavors are crisp, buttery, earthy. decent stuff.3.6.
Pours a cloudy copper color with a large foamy white head. Has hints of belgian yeast, candied sugar, sweet light fruits, spice. Finishes with a sweet yeasty taste.

341mL bottle, notched September 07 for the bottled on date.  Thanks to Denis beerbuzzmontreal for this one.  Clear golden amber with a 1 1/2 finger bone white head, good retention.  Aroma has definite Belgian characteristics--yeast, pear, apple--with some peppery notes and stale herbal hops.  Digging deeper there are notes of banana and earth.  Flavor had plenty of fruit again (with some added lemon zest) with the same peppery and hop dryness that I imagined itd have.  Not much sweetness to be had as far as I could tell.  Flavor did add an light acidic tang almost in the finish.  Semi-dry, earthy bitter (3 out of 10) finish.  Plenty of carbonation with a light to medium body.  Good stuff.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle. Great thick meringue head on hazy dark yellow. Delicate peppery spice nose. Highly spiced flavour. First taste seems mild then the aftertaste grows and grows. Hints of vanilla, pepper and banana. Second sip and all the flavours come together. Could get drunk night after night on this, tastes better each sip.

Bottle: Poured a deep dirty yellow color ale with a huge foamy head with perfect retention and some great lacing. Aroma of noble dry hops with some nice Belgian style malt. Taste is really dry and is totally dominated by some floral and dry hops with a nice Belgian malt structure. Body is above average with some limited filtration and perfect carbonation for the style. I believe we are just missing some wild yeast and we would have a perfect score.

Appearance: Hazy golden with a very thick and long lasting white head. Aroma: Very hoppy, citrus and floral. Sweet malt, spices and yeast. A very powerfull and pleasing nose. Flavor is grassy, citrusy with sweet malt, spices and a long bitter aftertaste. Another very good beer from Dieu du ciel

Bottled version - Cloudy blonde/golden poor with a nice thick foamy off-white head.  Aromas of corn, citrus, floral hops, coriander.  Lively effervescent, medium body.  Flavors are very spicy, citrus, orange, lemon, grapefruit... Nicely bitter and very refreshing... Not bad overall

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2012 bouteille brune de 341ml.

de belle couleur blonde, trouble à souhait, on dirait quelle est au blé, la mousse est insipide, le nez est bizarre, on ne sent pas les épices, en bouche le goût est prononcé, il est fort, très amère, on goute les houblons, houblonnage à froid, ce qui lui donne un goût de vert. ce nest pas ma préféré. 

Version à 7,0% alc. avec la nouvelle étiquette est plus savoureuse. Le houblon est plus frais. La note a été ajustée à cette nouvelle dégustation. Elle avait une note de 2.6.

Sample, at the Mondial de la biere 2006
June 2 2006; eye: hazy, caramel with straw reflections, tiny white head; nose: citrus, walk in a wood full of pine trees; mouth: freshness, mildly citrusy, full body, good carbonation

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, bue au Mondial de la bière 2006 le 2 juin 2006; oeil : voilée, caramel avec des reflets paille, petite mousse blanche; nez : citron, marche dans un bois de sapin; bouche : fraîcheur, moyennement citronnée, petite pointe dagrumes, pleine, bonne carbonatation

Bottle courtesy of Viper666. Pours a hazy bubbly yellow-gold with a massive long-lasting foamy white head. Aromas sweet and yeasty along with fruit, some hops and spices. Flavour starts with yeast and spices followed by sweet malt and fruit and finishes with hops. Medium bodied. Pretty good version of the style, I enjoyed it.
Bottle courtesy of beerbuzzmontreal.  A very nice, hoppy, spicy Belgian ale.  Very clean w/ a nice aromatic finish.  Very nice.  Best Canadian brewery?

bottle via trade in person with Glouglouburp.  Pours cloudy orange with a big stable off white head.  Nose is big and full of yeasty notes and lots of appealing spices.  Taste is sweet, spicy and very well balanced.  Has a nice spicy kick and a little underlying citrus Im guessing comes from some of the hops in the dry hopped description.  Nice beer, thanks dude.

Bouteille. Couleur or-orangée, mousse épaisse et très compacte, très persistente, traces beaucoup le verre, effervescence forte, voilée. Arôme de levure, dagrume, dépices, et de blé. Goût dépices, de blé, bien malté, légèrement alcool, forte amertume, et longue en finale. Corps moyen, effervescence moyenne à forte. Bière surprenante, jaime beaucoup son amertume, cest différent.

Ce nest pas la meilleure de la brasserie Dieu du ciel... mais encore une fois une bonne bière. Léger goût fruité avec une finale prononcée. Une bonne amertûme sans arrière goût. Présence dépices se fait remarquer.
UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 Excellente bière, comme toutes les bières que cette super micro-brasserie fait dailleurs. Un léger parfum, belle couleur, généreuse mousse, aucun arrière-gout, bon gout de miel.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dun fût, dégusté au Festival Bières et Saveurs 2007 (Chambly, QC). Arôme: Odeur dhoublons et dépices. Apparence: La couleur est blonde orangé voilée avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes et dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence dépices en arrière goût. (Rating #1218)
Sampled at Mondial de la Biere. I liked this one quite a bit. Reminded me of a Saison I had from Millys in NH. Had a similar smoked gouda, peppery flavor. Was very impressed with this one.
Hoppy aroma with some citrus and spice, clear yellow, small white head. Wheat flavoured, with some candied malt and lots of hops. Really interesting sensation in the mouth, unique. Very good!

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 Draught.  At Dieu du Ciel.  *dry-hopped version* Hazy gold with a small creamy white head.  Aroma of mild sweet candy malt, lightly wheaty grain, mild spice, and an overlay of pungent green hops.  Taste of spice and yeast, sweet malt with that almost weird green hop overlay - not balanced at all, and that hurts the overall taste.  Watery body, astringent and hop-bitter on the palate and in the longish finish - interesting experience, but not really a winner to me.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2009 In short: A very hoppy (juicy floral hops) Belgian Blonde Ale.  Original and very good.
How: Bottle 330ml, fresh (many of them, 12+).  Also many times on tap at the pub (12+ times)
The look: Partly cloudy light golden body with a large white head
In long: Very enticing nose of honeyed flowers.  Honey and petunias is what comes to my mind.  Taste is rather sweet with sugary honey flavour and texture.  Very yeasty but with only mild fruity notes of peaches and mangos.  Hopping takes a lot of room.  Not a lot of bitterness but instead very very juicy hop flavour. A little foresty not but overall very floral.  A short but sharp dry bitterness in the after-taste surprises after each sip.  A very atypical Belgian Ale.  Would also be atypical in any other style.  My own Dernière Volonté (Last Will) is that they throw in some dry and bitter hops and well have a masterpiece.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was cloudy orange with a white head. The aroma was grapefruit with funky brett type character. There was also some apples and cinnamon. The taste was funky with brett with some leather and apples. Interesting.
Robe dorée voilée surmontée dune mousse blanche qui persiste. Arômes de houblon herbacé résineux et floral. Saveurs de houblon herbacé, de céréales et de blé.
This beer has a mixture of different fruits with the aroma as well. It has a spicy aftertaste that is very pleasant in the mouth.

Je trouve que ce mélange des styles était peut-être un ptit peu trop osé. Arôme de houblon très végéta, et très étrange couplé avec les caractéristique dune bonne bière biere dabaye quelle pourrait offrir sans cela... Vraiment pas la meilleure du Dieu du Ciel!
Bu au Mondial de la Bière 04. Ce serait pas ma dernière volonté comme bière, mais elle est assé apréciable.

A hazy orange beer with a small white head. The aroma is malty with slight notes of smoke as well as wheat, while the flavor is sweet spicy with coriander standing out, but also with a clear wheat presence, leading to a dry end.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2008 Rerate 12 oz bottle. Pours a nice hazy blond great carbonation and a fluffy creamy white headp cool lace too.  aroma is lightly belgian yeast, peppery phenolic- light vanilla, earthy and herbal hops and some doughy creamy pils malts.  Awesomely fresh pilsner malt flavor- doughy cream of wheat, lightly prickly spicy hops, phenolics and a nice clean bitterness.  Great fluffy creamy smooth mouthfeel.  Sick belgian pale ale.  Last rate was 3 years ago on tap at DdC and I gave it a 3.4.  Something got way better.

Golden in color with medium haze and a white head. Quite fruity, plenty of pineapple and orange, Belgian yeast lending some banana character and the hop flavor is of an herbal quality. Interesting mix of the fruitiness and the herbal hoppiness. Light to medium bodied. Not bad but there are certainly better beers available here.
Draught at the brewpubBlonde color, lightly tangy yeast, citrusy and funky/sour yeast. The flavor is nice but tannic and "acidulous".

Lightly cloudy yellow-gold w/ a small, frothy white head. Fresh yeasty aroma of banana, pineapple, honey, coriander, clove & grassy hops. Light, somewhat grainy feel. Flavour is sweet & yeasty w/ a warming, peppery alcoholic finish.

Very nearly clear apple juice with a lightly lacing short white4 head. Leafy and sweet with pears, apples, and peach with some cream and honey. Soap flavours could come with a little coriander spicing. Floral clean and toasty. European hop and malt is balanced nicely. Quite tastey but simple.

cloudy gold, white head.  belgian yeast and clean malt aroma with honey and spicy notes and herbal hops.  starts malty with some coriander, has a hint of mango, then goes grassy and hoppy.  different and quie nice.

draft during RBSG visit - aromas of straw, honey, corriander, and banana coming from a cloudy yellow body, lots of grassy hops in the flavors, little bit of the fruits, nice spices, but the aftertaste  became very bitter.
UPDATED: SEP 19, 2008 Cloudy golden.  Big phenols are plasticy but somehow good.  Pear, alcohol, white pepper, complex fruits and peach.  Good body, nice subtle hoppiness.  Stylish, interesting brew.

Tap at RBSG05.  Banana-like sweet aroma with some doughy notes and honey aromas.  There are also some pine trees in this.  Mildly hazy blonde golden color with a white head.  Spicy, flowery, dandelion flavors to start.  Finishes very hopped with lots of pine.  This is pretty interesting.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2006 Aroma:wheat banana and good citrus hops..
Appearance:hazy gold,good white head...
Flavor:Full fruity,spicy,citrus hops and wheat banana....

Hazy golden honey hue, with thick white foamy head, with lacing, fruity, yeaty, soft floral hop aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with fruity flavors of citrus fruits, even peach and pineapple, yeasty, hoppy, floral hop in a peachy hop bittering finish.
(RBSG05) Hazy golden body topped by off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, herbal, honey.  Taste is medium sweet, honey, herbal, light pepper.  Light-medium body with some dryness in the finish.

Pour is gloudy golden yellow with a bright white head...smell was spicy corriander and clove...very witbier like...some honey as well...all of those things play into the flavor too, but seemed a little overly sweet...

2005 RBSG - Clove, banana esters on the nose.  Light spice, ginger, clove, banana, honey, very light on the palate.  Hint of hops to finish, this is decent.  If the palate were a little heavier it would really be good.

RBSG 2005 at DDC: Golden yellow body with a small white head. Weed, ginger and cut grass in the aroma. Flavor is all over the place- honey sweetness, weeds, hops, and ginger. A little banana also. Pretty sweet finish. Strange but good.

2005 RBSG Montreal Saturday. Pale golden colour with a frothy white head. Citrus accented aroma with notes of caramel, bread, and alcohol. Caramel, orange, and bready flavours with a citrus and piny bitter finish. Light bodied.

RBSG 2005... Poured a hazy, orange gold color with a medium sized, white head that left spotty lacing on the glass.  Aroma of marshmellow, vanilla, citrus, yeast and spices.  Taste of citrus, banana, lots of spices, yeast, and finished sweet.  Impressive!
Medium golden color, soft hoppy nose. The body is mildly rich and very soft with golden apples that is relatively sweet. The finish is rich and bitter.

Draught sample at the Mondial.  Pale, rather oily blonde with a bit of lasting snowy head...soft aroma comprised mainly of hay and honey but with underlying currents of nuts, cumin and white pepper helping to spice it up and keep in interesting...lightly yeasty body with a grainy, rough sugariness...almost feels like granular sugar has been added and not completely fermented or liquified...honey and orangey citric acid towards the finish, hops fairly muted...finishing sourness and acids dont balance the rather cloying sweetness...interesting but relative to most DDC offerings a mixed success.
draught. golden body with a small white head. fruity aroma with plenty of berries and yeast. sweet fruity flavour. body is a little over carbonated. an average ale.

On draught at the brewpub 6/2/2005 with Tiggmtl, Muzzlehatch and Bret Kuhnhenn and Co.  Pale golden-yellow colored beer, small white head with good retention and low lacing.  Looks rather still in the glass for a Belgian ale, however.  Aroma of light pale malts, some dry biscuits and touches of lemon and orange rind.  Fresh green hops greet the nose immediately backed by a brace of white sugar.  Some faint touches of yeast, but its passing.  Flavor is sweet, light grassy/plant-like bitterness, with dough and sugar, and a round, but too subtle/subdued Belgian yeast.  Dry spiciness gets almost bready on the end.  Mouthfeel is soft, almost buttery/creamy, with moderate carbonation, and a medium body overall.  Would like more Belgian yeast apparency and complexity and some dryer/more complex malts.
Cloudy yellow, good head, lace. Good carbonation. Dry hoppy finish, citrus spice yeast, medium mouthfeel. Mondiale 2005. Satisfying.

Hazy blond body topped with a thick white foamy head. Strong sweet/fruity aroma (apple, banana) with hints of hops, herbs, grass, and coriander. Taste is dominated by hoppiness, and hides the alcohol pretty well. Has a nice bitter finish and pleasanr warming effet. Interesting...

Hazy blonde, with light lacing.  Slightly citrusy, could use a bit more pop.   Maybe my nose was getting affected from the smoky pub... 
Taste is grassy, almost milky mouthfeel, with an excellent hop aftertaste and lip smacking dryness.  Reminds me of Hommelbier.

Draft... Hazy, golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Perfect, stratus lacework. The aroma delivers a lot of fuzzy fruit, apple and banana. The flavor is big; much bigger than the ABV indicates. Kind of alcoholic. Tastes more like a 9% ABV than 6% ABV, but I dont mind that. Apple, pear and apricot. Full-bodied and oily with lively carbonation. Lengthy, bitter-sweet and then bone dry finish.
Pours a cloudy blonde color with a thin white head. Appealing aroma of hops, citrus and yeast. Flavor of hops, citrus, yeast with a bitter finish. Light to medium body, creamy texture.  Good stuff.
Blonde beer with a rather floral hops aroma, almost pot-like. Extreme hops with slices of grapefruits and resins with a nice scotch like aftertaste, like a wonderful liqueur with hops.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Draught at the brewpub (August 2004) and subsequent bottle (April 2008). Fluffy, persistent white head and pale golden-orange body with steady effervescence.  Intense blended aroma of spice, whole oranges, vanilla and floral Saaz esters.  Flavor is remarkably dry with a nice combination of phenolics and bitterness.  Palate-numbing.   This is right in my wheelhouse.

(Draught) Mondial de la Bière 2004. Thin, white head and a clear gold body. Nose is spicy, cascade hops... GORGEOUS! Very spicy, hoppy as hell. The finish is a bitter hoppiness. An excellent Belgian Ale.

Light golden in colour, small white head.  Aroma was of mild spices, earth and hops.  Flavour was spicey, some pepper, hops, some lemons.  Medium body, mild carbonation.  Finishes slightly dry and hoppy.
Warm, spicy aroma , light Belgian . Hoppy front, vegetable, peppery middle. Sticky mouthfeel , yeasty finish .
Golden in color with a small white head. Hoppy aroma. Sweet malts,hoppy and fruity flavor.

Fruity, sweet malt aroma supports strong flowery, pine-like, woody hop nose. Slightly hazy, depp golden, caramel coloured body with two finger white head that lasts nicely. Strong hops subsumed with fruity sweet malts beneath. Pleasant lasting bitterness. Body is medium with good carbonation. Its definitely a tripel from the fruity sweetness, but the huge hops add an exciting twist. Very drinkable. On tap at the brewpub (sampled also at Mondial 2004).

Draft. Pale slightly hazy golden yellow with a nice white head. Interesting hoppy notes over top of the sweet alcoholic aromas Id expect from a triple.  Some peppery spicey notes in the aroma become more prominent in the flavour. Mouthfeel is on the light side. Mondiale 2T.

Clear straw golden body with gentle off-white head. Aroma is very piney, mineralic with grassy and leafy green hop tones. Spicy mint and lemongrass fruitiness (pears, oranges). Superb balance between dry-hopping and the belgian ale serving as fundation. Loads of grassy hops, lemon, mild apples and white grapefruit, yeasty. Delicate balance imo. Body could be bigger though, but the moderately high carbonation fits well. Coating aftertaste, bitter, sprucey. Very interesting.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2010 (October 2007, bottled batch): The dry-hopped aroma is not as prominent as some batches Ive tasted at the brewpub, but the spicy hop edges tickle all the way to the finish. The head on this one never dies, the body is rich and soothing for this gravity, the mouthfeel is authentically Belgian, and the flavor profile is smooth and balanced. This is as professional as it gets, folks. A top notch Belgian Ale which wont wow because of its idiosyncracies, but which cannot be objectively criticized.

(April 2006 batch): Aromas gotten a lot spicier, lots of ginger fruitiness, which works well with the dry hoppiness...This is becoming a unique Belgian ale with a funky Thai twist!

(January 2005 batch): Dry-hopping is still prevalent but much more amicable...Flavors are extremely well-blended, and malt, hops and spiciness all converge for a beautiful rendition of a North American Single Abbey Ale...Top notch stuff and, in this form, maybe my favorite Belgian they make...

(First try) : Gargantuan dry-hopped nose, grassy marine life à la Quintessence, a tad too intense for now, covering multiple pale fruit underneath...Honey malt sweetness surges to balance it all out, but the fresh hops still dominate...A frail body entices the tongue to take advantage of it, with multiple pleasurable gulps, all intense in flavor.

5th beer of the 2004 Montreal Mondiale. Clear yellow, medium head. Ok, the aroma and the flavour are both quite a lot like pot, before its smoked, it must be the dry-hopping, something I dont think I have yet to have in a beer. Im not sure if I really like this, but it is interesting.
